story:
About the Founders

Hussam, the husband and co-principal of The Free Syria School was a lawyer and early leader in the Free Aleppan Lawyers Association, a group of pro-democracy attorneys. After nearly a year of public and private activism to support the popular democratic movement Hussam's car went up in flames as he prepared to return home from the office. The bomb had been planted regime operatives. Hussam went into hiding with his family when other pro-democracy attorneys in Aleppo were reported killed, or worse, kidnapped and tortured.

The Free Syria School

Hussam recognizes that the future of Syria lies in the education and empowerment of Syrian children. With the little money Hussam and his wife Maysaa managed to collect before escaping Syria, they started a school in a Turkish border city that has become a hub for Syrian refugees and their children.

In addition to their traditional curriculum, "we teach the students the difference between a democracy and an autocracy, the difference between having a say in the world around them and not having a voice at all" Hussam explains.

What the School Means to Students

It comes as no surprise that the terms freedom, democracy, and 'saving Syria' are repeated in the student-prepared posters and essays pinned to the walls of the humble Free Syria School. Not only is the education free, the 300+ students are believing in freedom as a cornerstone of their national spirit.

 

Emergency Appeal

The Free Syria School is facing a funding gap of $8,000. With no money to renew the lease of the classrooms or to cover the meager wages of refugee educators, the school will be shut-down.

 

The school has been running for over 6 months now.

 

Visit the school's Facebook page to take a closer look at what you have the opportunity to support. 

 

*This campaign was initiated by two Syrian Americans who had the opportunity to visit the school while delivering aid to displaced Syrians in the region.

story:
I found this video incredible. A young man, fed up with the lack of care from his teacher, stood up to say EXACTLY what she needs to hear and EXACTLY what the American people need to hear about our failing public education. 

 

This young man is very courageous and it is sad that a student has to demand his teacher to teach.  We need a higher level of feedback and control over what our kids are experiencing in the class room.

 

I say we, the collective of the internet assures that Jeff Bliss gets a college education or is allowed to attend a local private school of his choosing.  

 

Lets raise $100,000 to assure that Jeff can fullfill his dreams of doing and being whatever he wants to be in life.

 


Lets do this!

story:
A MASSIVE THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT 


About MyRefuge

'MyRefuge' is conceived as like an AirBnB for refugees, with no money involved. People who want to open up their homes to refugees can say how many beds they have available and for which periods of time. Refugees can book beds for however long they are available. 

There are already a number of national initiatives organised by NGOs or grassroots movements aimed at opening up their homes and communities to refugees. MyRefuge aims to bring these initiatives together by building a global community of people who want to help refugees. MyRefuge will also step things up a bit: it will be like Uber & AirBnB by simultaneously enabling direct connection between refuge provider and refuge seeker, as well as provide a vetting process with regards to asylum status and building in direct access to front line services and NGOs so that all relationships formed can be properly supported.

We are over 50% of the way through on building a basic prototype. We've done a lot of the backend and front end, registration process is complete for both refuge seekers and refuge providers and now we are implementing the search and communication features. We want to finish the prototype soon so that we can meet the interest that exists right now for example in the massive (90,000+ strong) demonstration Saturday in London. 

Our aims at this stage is simple: show governments tangibly that there are people who WILL welcome refugees into their homes and communities, provide a way for everyone to be able to offer practical help to refugees, and to make it easy for NGOs and local services to support those who want to help.

If you want to join the growing global community to open up their homes,  please help us build this app. 

If you want to get involved with the project, whether as a developer or in other ways, please get in touch with us via https://www.facebook.com/MyRefugeApp


What We Need & What You Get

It is simple: we need money to make sure that MyRefuge servers don't crash and to make sure that we can have the right development skills in the team to ensure an app that is secure, bug-free, and agile so that it can quickly evolve to meet the needs of the refugee communities and those who want to open up their homes to them. 

Our current development plan for MyRefuge is as follows 

  • In the next week to have a prototype ready for people to begin registering their free beds and for refugees to sign up and find those welcoming homes, in countries and cities of their choosing (based on availability of course). That is what the £1000 aims to cover. 
  • In the next month, to build in App infrastructure connecting governments and NGOs into relationships between refugees and households opening their doors to them. Governments, for example, will need to confirm asylum status so that refuge-provider and refuge-seeker relationships can be finalised. Relevant NGOs and local service providers can be notified by the system of refuge-provider / refuge-seeker relationships being formed and will be able to communicate with both parties to ensure relevant support is provided, whether through workshops, advice / resources etc.  
  • In two months, MyRefuge to help facilitate support like language tutoring, mentoring, clothing etc from willing donors to organisations organising that kind of support in different countries. 
Of course, the more we raise beyond £1000, the faster we'll be able to develop MyRefuge so it can do all the incredible things we want it to do. £1000 will merely ensure we can get the prototype out. Thank you for your support!! 

The Impact

There are over 4 million refugees from Syria living in camps, with hundreds of thousands drowning as they try to make their way across dangerous waters to safe and secure countries. There are also millions of refugees from other conflicts in Africa and elsewhere. As humanity, we cannot sit by and watch these catastrophes unfold. Governments are struggling to deal with the problem. We believe citizens need to show governments that there is a political will and citizen resources for us to support refuge seekers in their time of crisis. 

When we open up their homes to refugees, we 

  • Communicate a simple human and universal message: we care
  • Make it much easier for refugees to join our communities in a loving atmosphere, and to receive the kind of personal and de-bureaucratised support they really need to succeed in their new environments 
  • Have an impact on generations to come. Nobody will forget the kindness, ever. 
We are a grassroots movement, and MyRefuge will be 100% Open Source. Furthermore, we are 100% committed to work with all organisations - government, NGOs and grassroots - needed in this space in order to make sure that the lives of people that have been shattered by the wars taking place around the world can be pieced together in our communities. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!!

story:
Mindfield “Socks for Hope” Drive – Christmas 2015

Every year the Salvation Army Harbour Light puts together Christmas Care Packages for people in need on the DTES. Items include ponchos, toiletries, clothes, and of course, SOCKS! Mindfield is here to support their efforts once again by doing a Sock Drive to add to these packages, as we know dry socks are the biggest need for people living on the streets.

The Goal:

As a company, Mindfield would like to BEAT last years’ achievement of collecting 3,000 pairs of socks for the Salvation Army!

The Initiative:

The Mindfield team will be broken down into 7 groups of 11. Each group will compete against one another to bring in the highest number of socks per team.
To reach 3,000 pairs company-wide: Each group’s goal should be apx: 428 pairs of socks- just under 40 pairs per person.

How you can help:

As our friends and family, we would like to ask for your support - any amount of donation helps. Your donation can come in the form of cash or SOCKS! The socks have to be brand new of course; however they can be any brand or style.

The Deadline:

Friday, December 4th 2015.

story:
My Daughter Jess (16)  is Raising Money for a Water Project in Ethopia to bring vital clean supplies to this isolated school.

Jess Says;

I am a student who is trying very hard to raise money to travel to Tigray province in Ethiopia in the summer of this year. I will be going along with 11 other students and together we will be laying over 1 km worth of water piping to a remote village school in the Ethiopian highlands. The school at the moment has no water access and the children have to travel to school carrying huge buckets of water from home. With the help of my friends and me the school will have access to clean running water to use for cooking and hygiene for the children.

 
To achieve this however I will have to raise £2,450 by myself. 
 
I am selling fudge and have done various small jobs in my holidays to try and achieve this aim. I have raised a total of £400 so far, almost enough to cover my first deposit on the trip.
 
Follow my Blog http://service-ethiopia.blogspot.co.uk/
 
So this blog will be a way of keeping track of my fundraising efforts to make sure i can get to Ethiopia, when i return there will be a full detailed account with pictures of my trip so that anyone who reads this blog or who has supported me can see exactly what I did with the money and the amazing experiences that I will have in Ethiopia!

story:
About Me:

A relentless optimist out to change the world.

Growing up in the culturally, politically, and economically disparate contexts of Mexico and the United States has shaped my worldview. As a result, I believe each of us, regardless of gender, ethnicity, or socioeconomic background deserves access to the health, educational, and economic resources that are so crucial for our advancement as human beings. I am driven on a daily basis to make the manifestation of these values a reality worldwide. Starting in June I will travel to India as an IDEX Fellow and continue my life’s work: finding solutions to the developing world’s most serious humanitarian challenges.

 

About The Fellowship:

The IDEX fellowship is a 6-month program that offers professional, cultural and social immersion for talented individuals interested in launching careers in the social enterprise sector. Specifically, IDEX places fellows alongside local entrepreneurs in innovative game changing organizations they’ve created for communities in India, and the world. Together, by blending our individual strengths, we will develop and implement an action plan for realizing change. Learn more about the IDEX Fellowship here: http://www.idexfellows.com/                                                         

I have been placed in Bangalore, with QUEST (Quality Education and Skills Training) Alliance. QUEST Alliance was founded in 2005 under the International Youth Foundation and USAID, to promote the use of technology to enhance the quality and relevance of education and vocational training in India. QUEST works to build stronger curriculum and pedagogy for youth employability programs, as well as develop sustainable models to enable them to scale by leveraging ICT based solutions. Learn more about Quest Alliance here: http://www.questalliance.net/

With Quest I will be working to establish linkages with existing employers in technical trades, creating a regular system of interaction within industries, understanding the current placement systems at the government and private industrial training institutes, creating post placement tracking systems of youth and more.

 

My Background:

In December, 2012, I earned a Bachelor’s Degree in Economics.

I currently work with “Opportunity Fund,” a not-for-profit social enterprise helping thousands of California families build financial stability, evaluating their microenterprise small business loans and savings program. Their holistic strategy combines microloans for small businesses, microsavings accounts, and community real estate financing. They are California’s leading and largest microfinance provider. You can learn more about Opportunity Fund here: http://www.opportunityfund.org/

Additionally, for “IntrinsicStyles”, a social enterprise dedicated to empowering communities in developing nations via creative, holistic, and sustainable business, I work on business development and brand awareness. You can learn more about IntrinsicStyles here: http://www.intrinsicstyles.com/

 

Why and How you can help:

I have worked hard over the past few months and have secured scholarship funds to cover the program costs and most of the living expenses. I need your help getting me to India and back by funding my plane tickets and basic pre-departure medical expenses.

Donate and be part of this mission to change the world. Small or large, every donation helps, honestly! Your contribution will directly support the profound, positive, and transformative change happening in India today.

 

Other ways you can help:

If a donation will have to wait or you want to help even more, share this page with your coworkers, friends and/or family to help raise awareness for my campaign and the IDEX vision, inspiring others to join this movement. The generosity of complete strangers humbles and inspires me. They just need an opportunity to be generous, share my campaign and they will have that opportunity.

You can also help connect me with your friends in India. Since the IDEX Fellowship will send me to India and the vibrant people within it for the first time, familiar faces will definitely help me acclimate and learn.

 

Thank you!

To all of you who contribute, share my story, or have simply taken the time to read through my campaign, thank you from the bottom of my heart. My dream, a life dedicated to enacting positive, global change, has only become possible because of people like you lifting me along the way. I consider it a responsibility to ensure that your faith in me leads to our mutual benefit. We’re in this together.

story:
15 in 50 Matching Grant!

That's right - every donation you make through Thursday night at 9:00pm, will be DOUBLED up to $1,500!  So if you're waiting till the last minute to make a contribution, now is the time!  Don't you want your gift to count for double?


Our Story

Sometimes what works for everyone else, just doesn't work for you.

That was the case for the Sachs family. They wanted a school that would support their children's individual gifts, and nurture a love of learning.

A Montessori school seemed perfect; but the nearest school was too expensive and too far away. Homeschooling was promising, but too daunting to attempt alone.

What they needed was a combination of the two. Something that didn't exist.


But then, it did.

Family Montessori is a new idea, a combination of traditional homeschooling and a Montessori classroom. For half the week, students learn in a beautiful Montessori environment. The other half, students are educated at home by their parents. Certified Montessori teachers bridge the gap between the formal classroom and home school by providing support and training specifically tailored to each family.

There are many families who want to join Family Montessori, but can't afford to, despite our intentionally low tuition. This campaign is our effort to keep tuition at a minimum and start a scholarship fund so that these families can benefit. Your donation will help us share this amazing education with more children.

Our goal is to serve the:

Child

We believe education is about a child’s social, emotional and academic development. Each child is unique with their own learning style. Family Montessori engages every child at their level, helping them develop at their own pace. Respect, grace and courtesy are key facets of our curriculum.

Family

We make an intentional effort to support the most important people in each child’s life – their parents! Parent workshops, mom's meetings and potlucks are some of the means we use to support and encourage our families.

Community

We want to help our children become well-educated, thoughtful adults who have a strong sense of community. Service projects like serving lunches to the less fortunate and singing at nursing homes, provide opportunities to invest in others.


FAQ

Why should I support a new educational innovation when I don’t even have children in school?

We are all in this together. Each child grows up to either become a positive influence on your society or a burden to it. When we invest in children, we invest in a brighter future for our whole community.

Why should I support Family Montessori when I already pay taxes for Public schools?

If you have ever struggled in school or had a child who struggled in school, you understand that one size doesn't fit all. Although Lebanon has quality schools and our teachers are doing a heroic job, some kids are just better served in a different environment. We are here to serve those children and families. Do your public school a favor: help provide an alternative for these children.

Why should I support a Montessori hybrid when I am an established Montessorian?

Let’s face it, Montessori schools are expensive. We are making Montessori education affordable for a whole demographic of families who couldn't otherwise afford it. Furthermore, our hybrid structure helps parents understand and truly value the Montessori philosophy.

Why should I support a home school hybrid when I support traditional home schooling?

Some families would love to home school their children but don’t because it seems like too big of a challenge. Family Montessori’s hybrid structure gives families who would otherwise not try home schooling, the support and confidence to jump in.

Like any parenting choice, education decisions can be potentially controversial and divisive. Many people complain and quarrel about education but that doesn't help children or parents. We are not here to debate which method is best. We simply want to share a completely new idea that happens to be working quite well. Our motto is: “Learn and let learn”


Our Results

There is no other school out there like Family Montessori. A place that brings together the most important elements of a child’s life – education, family and community. We’re only two years old, but the successes we've had in our short existence have been staggering - just check out the comments to see what our families are saying!

Our Mission

To create an educational structure that serves children, supports families, and builds community.

Our Core Values

1. High Quality Education: We want our children to have an excellent education that nurtures their intrinsic love of learning, lets them develop at their own pace and instills respect for self, others and their environment.

2. Affordable: By keeping costs low, we make tuition more affordable. We want any family to be able to participate regardless of socio-economic status.

3. Local Intergenerational Community: Community is a rare and precious gift and community thrives in proximity. FM creates a structure that allows child, parent and grandparent generations to connect and enrich each other's lives.

4. Service: We want our children to learn to give as well as receive; to grow through serving others. FM provides opportunities for students and their families to engage in service projects throughout the course of the year.

5. Judeo-Christian Roots: Our classrooms reflect our faith traditions in terms of holiday celebrations and prayer before meals. However, we do not offer a specific religious curriculum. We welcome anyone from any tradition who wishes to be part of a community of grace.

How you can help!

1. Please donate - It’s tax deductible!

We want Family Montessori to be around for the long-term, helping children and families long into the future. It takes $4,000 to support one student for one year. Any amount you can give will hugely help a child who needs it.

2. Spread the word!

Share this campaign through Email, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or G+ It’s like multiplying your own donation! Anytime you share us with a friend who donates, you’ve added to your contribution.

3. Picture this!

Donate your profile picture by using this image instead through 3/14. When people ask what it’s about, point them our way!


A MASSIVE Thank You!

* First thank YOU! Your donations, and social sharing help our group more than you can know. You are such an encouragement and we are so grateful for your confidence in us.

* Thank you to our Board of Directors and the Vision Team for all of the hard work and prayerful care poured out on behalf of our school.

* Thank you to Fred and Dianne Remmers for the amazing donation of Montessori materials.

* Thank you to Lebanon Presbyterian Church, New Freedom Church, and St. Patrick's church for the generous use of your space.

* Thank you to our dedicated staff and teachers for their love and support of our families.

* Thank you to Visionhousepro for the incredible video they created.

* Thank you to Tracy at Hall of Fame Moms for featuring Family Montessori, and helping us spread the word to a whole new community of Homeschoolers.

* Thank you to Beka at Altered by Hope for giving a blog post when we just asked for a share. You always go above and beyond.

* And thank you to our friends and families, for daring to catch the vision and run with it too.

--

Please note: when you donate, your receipt will say "Warren County Foundation". The Warren County Foundation, a registered 501(c)(3) organization, is the fiscal sponsor of Family Montessori of Lebanon. Donations to Family Montessori via WCF are tax-deductible.
story_txt:
15 in 50 Matching Grant!That's right - every donation you make through Thursday night at 9:00pm, will be DOUBLED up to $1,500!  So if you're waiting till the last minute to make a contribution, now is the time!  Don't you want your gift to count for double?
Our Story
Sometimes what works for everyone else, just doesn't work for you.That was the case for the Sachs family. They wanted a school that would support their children's individual gifts, and nurture a love of learning.A Montessori school seemed perfect; but the nearest school was too expensive and too far away. Homeschooling was promising, but too daunting to attempt alone.What they needed was a combination of the two. Something that didn't exist.
But then, it did.
Family Montessori
is a new idea, a combination of traditional homeschooling and a Montessori
classroom.  For half the week, students learn in a beautiful
Montessori environment. The other half, students are educated at
home by their parents. Certified Montessori teachers bridge the gap between the
formal classroom and home school by providing support and training specifically
tailored to each family.
There are many
families who want to join Family Montessori, but can't afford to, despite our
intentionally low tuition. This campaign is our effort to keep tuition at a
minimum and start a scholarship fund so that these families can benefit. Your
donation will help us share this amazing education with more children.
Our goal is to
serve the:
Child
We believe
education is about a child’s social, emotional and academic development. Each
child is unique with their own learning style. Family Montessori engages every
child at their level, helping them develop at their own pace. Respect, grace
and courtesy are key facets of our curriculum.
Family
We make an
intentional effort to support the most important people in each child’s life –
their parents! Parent workshops, mom's meetings and potlucks are some of the
means we use to support and encourage our families.
Community
We want to help
our children become well-educated, thoughtful adults who have a strong sense of
community. Service projects like serving lunches to the less fortunate and
singing at nursing homes, provide opportunities to invest in others.
FAQ
Why should I
support a new educational innovation when I don’t even have children in school?
We are all in this
together. Each child grows up to either become a positive influence on your society or a burden to it. When we invest in children, we invest in a brighter
future for our whole community.
Why should I
support Family Montessori when I already pay taxes for Public schools?
If you have ever
struggled in school or had a child who struggled in school, you understand that
one size doesn't fit all. Although Lebanon has quality schools and our teachers
are doing a heroic job, some kids are just better served in a different
environment. We are here to serve those children and families. Do your public
school a favor: help provide an alternative for these children.
Why should I
support a Montessori hybrid when I am an established Montessorian?
Let’s face it, Montessori schools are expensive. We are making Montessori education affordable
for a whole demographic of families who couldn't otherwise afford it.
Furthermore, our hybrid structure helps parents understand and truly value the
Montessori philosophy.
Why should I
support a home school hybrid when I support traditional home schooling?
Some families
would love to home school their children but don’t because it seems like too
big of a challenge. Family Montessori’s hybrid structure gives families who
would otherwise not try home schooling, the support and confidence to jump in.
Like any parenting
choice, education decisions can be potentially controversial and divisive. Many
people complain and quarrel about education but that doesn't help children or
parents. We are not here to debate which method is best. We simply want to
share a completely new idea that happens to be working quite well. Our motto
is: “Learn and let learn”
Our Results
There is no other
school out there like Family Montessori. A place that brings together the most
important elements of a child’s life – education, family and community. We’re
only two years old, but the successes we've had in our short existence have
been staggering - just check out the comments to see what our families are saying!
Our Mission
To create an
educational structure that serves children, supports families, and builds
community.
Our Core Values
1. High Quality
Education: We want our children to have an excellent education that nurtures
their intrinsic love of learning, lets them develop at their own pace and
instills respect for self, others and their environment.
2. Affordable: By
keeping costs low, we make tuition more affordable. We want any family to be
able to participate regardless of socio-economic status.
3. Local
Intergenerational Community: Community is a rare and precious gift and
community thrives in proximity. FM creates a structure that allows child,
parent and grandparent generations to connect and enrich each other's lives.
4. Service: We
want our children to learn to give as well as receive; to grow through serving
others. FM provides opportunities for students and their families to engage in
service projects throughout the course of the year.
5. Judeo-Christian
Roots: Our classrooms reflect our faith traditions in terms of holiday
celebrations and prayer before meals. However, we do not offer a specific
religious curriculum. We welcome anyone from any tradition who wishes to be
part of a community of grace.
How you can help!
1. Please donate -
It’s tax deductible!
We want Family
Montessori to be around for the long-term, helping children and families long
into the future. It takes $4,000 to support one student for one year. Any
amount you can give will hugely help a child who needs it.
2. Spread the
word!
Share this
campaign through Email, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or G+ It’s like
multiplying your own donation! Anytime you share us with a friend who donates,
you’ve added to your contribution.
3. Picture this!
Donate your profile picture by
using this image instead through 3/14. When people ask what it’s about, point
them our way!
A MASSIVE Thank
You!
* First thank YOU!
Your donations, and social sharing help our group more than you can know. You
are such an encouragement and we are so grateful for your confidence in us.
* Thank you to our
Board of Directors and the Vision Team for all of the hard work and prayerful
care poured out on behalf of our school.
* Thank you to
Fred and Dianne Remmers for the amazing donation of Montessori materials.
* Thank you to
Lebanon Presbyterian Church, New Freedom Church, and St. Patrick's church for
the generous use of your space.
* Thank you to our
dedicated staff and teachers for their love and support of our families.
* Thank you to
Visionhousepro for the incredible video they created.
* Thank you to Tracy at Hall of Fame Moms for featuring Family Montessori, and helping us spread the word to a whole new community of Homeschoolers.* Thank you to Beka at Altered by Hope for giving a blog post when we just asked for a share. You always go above and beyond.* And thank you to
our friends and families, for daring to catch the vision and run with it too.--Please note: when you donate, your receipt will say "Warren County Foundation". The Warren County Foundation, a registered 501(c)(3) organization, is the fiscal sponsor of Family Montessori of Lebanon. Donations to Family Montessori via WCF are tax-deductible.

story:
Short Summary

StartupYatra was born out of a need to impact India's entrepreneurship ecosystem. A country with over billion people and 30 million SMEs has not yet given birth to an Apple, Google or Facebook. With over a million engineers passing out each year, there is a need to stir people into action. 

Imagine a group of 20-25 people (we call them Yatris) meeting the founder (we call them Gurus) of a successful company, getting to know about his humble beginning, seeing his office, meeting the team members, learning about their operations and spending time with fellow aspiring entrepreneurs - this is what StartupYatra does; it creates infinite possibilities!

Nurture Talent Academy has conducted over 450+ workshops, across 125+ cities and trained over 30000+ students in last 4 years - our aim is to motivate more than a 1000 people to create 20000 jobs for India.

StartupYatra can multiply that impact 100 times over. If you are interested to know more details, please check out www.nurturetalent.com/startup-yatra

What We Need & What You Get

An initiative like StartupYatra takes dedicated efforts towards logistics, planning and marketing. Scheduling sessions in Guru's office, spreading out the word, handling queries, collecting registrations, managing volunteers, coordinating programs on the day of event and post-event follow ups require constant monitoring and instant action. 
It costs about 25-30 Lakhs to manage a year of 500+ StartupYatra sessions (approx 50000 USD). The event is free to attend for startups, professionals and students, as our aim is to create a vibrant community of entrepreneurs.

It is like organizing an OLYMPICS every day!
An initiative of this scale relies on society and community for support, success and sustenance. We have received sponsorship for few StartupYatra events in the past, and with your support, we are looking to take it farther and faster this year.
You can contribute as little as $5, in which case we will acknowledge you with a thanks on our social networks, or as much as $1000, in which case we will devote a whole month of StartupYatra to you and your brand with maximum visibility in both offline and online circles!

The Impact

I (Amit Grover) have been running NurtureTalent's various initiatives for last 4 years and prior to that handling operations at Mumbai Angels, India's premium angel investment network for 3 years before quitting to start my own venture for training and mentoring entrepreneurs. I spend most of my days and nights traveling to take entrepreneurship education to India's villages, towns, tehsils. There is a 9 out of 10 chance I have seen any city's railway station, bus stand or airport. And we have trained over 30000+ people - including school students, college students, professionals and startups.

Please check out few of the event photos listed on www.amitgrover.co.in But nothing makes us more happy than someone telling us "Sir, do you remember I came for your workshop sometime back - I have launched my business now, thanks :-)"

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love what I am doing, then help us by any means (even if you cannot donate money):

  • Tell your friends about StartupYatra, and ask them to join any of upcoming events.
  • Use share button to spread the word in your social networks - who knows someone in your network may help.

Thanks, and be awesome!

story:
"There is a time in the life of every problem when it is big enough to see, yet small enough to solve."

January is National Mentoring Month. Each One Save One is a leader, the first of its kind – a school based, 99% volunteer-run, non-profit mentoring program which recruits, screens, trains, and supports mentors for at-risk children.  Each One Save One (EOSO) was started in 1994 by us, WWL-TV Morning Anchor, Sally-Ann Roberts, and Cathy Harris.  That’s 20 years!  We wanted to make a difference in children’s lives and recognized that if like-minded individuals, and businesses would join us in mentoring efforts, it would have a positive impact in the lives of children. EOSO is celebrating this anniversary with Mentor Magic Gala on January 16 at the Hyatt Regency New Orleans. Join us for a great time, New Orleans style, celebrating and honoring our community’s mentoring heroes, both individuals and organizations. Mentoring works! Be someone who matters to someone who matters. Support Each One Save One, the Mentor Magic Gala and our mentoring heroes.

Hear Arnie Fielkow, a former mentor, New Orleans City Councilman and former Exec. V.P. for the New Orleans Saints urge support of Each One Save One.

A mentor helps

  • expand a child’s world and widen her view to more possibilities and life choices
  • serve as a positive role model
  • a child feel heard, that he is worth listening to, that he matters
  • a child discover techniques and strategies for solving problems whether with learning school work or with social skills

    Each One Save One is an extremely “lean” organization, usually having 1-3 paid employees and a working, volunteer board.  We need your support for Each One Save One’s upcoming Mentor Magic Gala celebrating our 20th year anniversary by honoring Robin Roberts, EOSO mentors, and other mentoring heroes in our community. Join us! Remember empower one child, empower generations.

    REWARDS

    Your support can actually change lives of children. We have more great rewards for you! Highlights include:

    --A Young and the Restless tour with your guide,Christian LeBlanc, aka Michael Baldwin, star of the Young and the Restless, the highest rated tv soap opera for decades. WOW!

    --Christian LeBlanc's autographed picture!

    --Mentor Magic Gala tickets featuring our favorites including Robin Roberts, Angela Hill, Christian LeBlanc, Eric Paulsen, Sally-Ann Roberts and Metro New Orleans own mentoring heroes. Bring friends! Live away? New Orleans is a great place to visit. Join us!

    --Sponsorships – positively impact lives; get great exposure for your business! Shout out for your family!

    IMPACT/CHALLENGES/RISKS

    We need your support now! Empower a child and empower generations!  Each One Save One has volunteers and staff with a passion to empower children and lead them on a path to reach their dreams.  We’ve fulfilled this mission for twenty years and are dedicated to continuing to do so.

    Hmmmmm...you know what guys...we should put on a gala!!!

    The goal is to raise the much needed funds to continue in EOSO’s mission and to hold our first mission-sustaining gala.  In the unlikely scenario where we do not raise enough funds, all monies raised will go to sustain the lean organization’s training, recruiting and supporting of mentors.

    OTHER WAYS YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE  All contributions are gratefully accepted. You amplify your contribution by helping us spread the word. For updates and contests:   "Like” us on facebook.  Follow us on Twitter. Email, text, post on facebook and Instagram, tweet, and talk about the Mentor Magic Gala. #MyBrothersKeeper #SomeoneWhoMatters #NationalMentoringMonth

    Extra - The story of co-founder Sally Ann's mother's mentor, her impact and how it inspired the founding and naming of Each One Save One:  http://neworleanscitybusiness.com/blog/2014/12/02/each-one-save-one-to-honor-mentors-mission/

story:
I’ll start with our story.  As you know,our high school (TJ) is a fast paced, highly stressful community of students hoping to excel. However, not all of us are proficient at everything we do so inherently we have problems reaching the ambitious goals we set for ourselves.  For too long I’ve seen too many of my classmates struggle. Some are questioning their abilities, some are disappointed in their performances in class, while others are motivated to learn more. They just need a little push, a helping nudge, in the right direction.  We decided to create Lumos+ out of this necessity, a website that connects students with experienced tutors in an efficient, enriching, and enjoyable fashion.  We want to show our peers and many more out there that they haven’t failed,  we want to show that they can bring that C up to an A or get that perfect score on their next chemistry test.

Lumos+, our nonprofit organization, was born out of the idea, that when people struggle it is our responsibility to lend a helping hand.  Our mission is to provide free online tutoring to all who seek it, so that no one has to feel powerless ever again.  

As a nation we’re 7th in literacy, 27th in math, and 22nd in science. We have problems.  Lumos+ can be the solution.  Lumos+ has the potential to become a kingpin, by providing that helping hand that’s so severely lacking in our education system.

Lumos+ is based off of a free membership model. Members can join their friends in a social media unit called a classroom.  A classroom includes not only discussion boards, but also interactive video chats; furthermore, these video chat have the capability to connect with a repertoire of a growing network of tutors - ranging from experts to peers in countless fields.

However, the biggest obstacle we face from achieving our goal is funding. What we ask of you is a donation; a donation to help provide a perfect supplement to assist children of all grades around the country, a donation to provide an eclectic source of useful information to all those in need, a donation to give a complacent smile to a student who is happy to receive an A on their final exam.  We reach out to you today inspired by your work, in hope that you will contribute to our nonprofit, Lumos+, and help us achieve our goal to have an easily accessible tutoring service available for students everywhere in the world.

story:
Since 2010, Albuquerque police officers have been involved in dozens of shootings, many of them fatal. Millions of dollars in taxpayer money has been paid out by verdict and by settlement in civil lawsuits.

A Department of Justice report released in April detailed a troubled and complex relationship between police officers, public officials, and residents of Albuquerque, particularly those facing a mental illness.

The report (embedded below) described the problem as “a culture of aggression” and noted that leadership had failed to provide proper civilian / internal oversight, and training. The result: Albuquerque police officers too often use deadly force or near-deadly force inappropriately.

We believe that access to public records and a serious look at each shooting is needed to reduce sensationalism around the topic, and encourage all stakeholders (including policymakers and law enforcement) to examine the “culture of aggression” outlined by the DOJ.




OUR PROJECT:

One of the most troubling issues suggested by the DOJ report is a lack of transparency.

Police and city officials have been evasive and at times outright refused to provide information requested by city councilors/policymakers, journalists, and Albuquerque residents - including the families of those fatally shot by police officers.

In part because of this lack of transparency, local, national and international news outlets have frequently focused on the most sensational aspects of the James Boyd case and other shootings. Media outlets have also been quick to draw conclusions that mischaracterize police, policymakers, shooting victims and their families, and Albuquerque's community at large.

The New Mexico Compass requested and received public records related to over two dozen of the shootings from 2010 - present, including officers’ lapel cam footage and belt-tape audio recordings, along with witness interviews, reports and other materials.


We will use funds raised via this campaign to:


a)  Create a searchable, interactive database of public records around each fatal shooting (taking cues from models like ProPublica’s Dollars for Docs project, as well as the ChicagoCrime and Homicide Watch projects).

Members of the community, policy makers, and local, regional and national journalists will be able to examine public records related to each specific shooting. Anyone is also welcome to suggest or contribute additional public records they have access to or are aware of.

b)  Develop, report, and present comprehensive stories surrounding the fatal shooting cases we received public records for.

c)  Provide a small stipend (around 25 percent of the total project cost) for our full time staff while we begin the process of raising a comprehensive operating budget.

We believe this project will provide a model for transparency in data and storytelling, and we hope it will encourage other journalists and organizations to answer questions like these:

“How does the public perceive journalism?”

“How can journalists evolve to improve the level of public trust in the press?”

“What does a more active, transparent and open-source flow of communication between the public and the press look like?”


ABOUT US



Editor in Chief Marisa Demarco has been a journalist for more than a decade and a musician all her life. A native New Mexican, she is co-founder of the New Mexico Compass, and works at KUNM News producing radio reports on 89.9 FM. Demarco has worked at the Weekly Alibi, the Albuquerque Tribune and the Daily Lobo.




Managing Editor Margaret Wright is a writer, editor, occasional photographer and proud New Mexican. Before diving into journalism full time, she taught refugee youth and immigrant adults, supervised a federally funded nonprofit program, and provided therapeutic case management for at-risk families. She is co-founder of the New Mexico Compass and former managing editor of Albuquerque’s alternative newsweekly, the Alibi.


Deputy Director Joe Cardillo joined the New Mexico Compass after six years of operations, product, and marketing experience in both legacy and startup environments. He’s passionate about data, design, open access, rocanroll, anything science-y and thinking about how to become a better human.


ABOUT THE NEW MEXICO COMPASS


The New Mexico Compass is a nonprofit startup dedicated to transparent, open-access journalism.

Combined with the educational efforts of its parent organization, the New Mexico Journalism Collaborative, the Compass strives to be a model for reporting that strengthens the community and contributes to a healthy journalism ecosystem.

All content at the New Mexico Compass adheres to the Society of Professional Journalists Code of Ethics. Editors follow the Associated Press Stylebook. 

Our editorial process and output maintain a strict firewall against outside influences, particularly from funding sources. The Compass is also committed to organizational transparency. Complete financial reports are publicly accessible on our website. 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

  • If you aren't able to donate to the campaign, please share it with your contacts on social networks and via email.

  • You can find us online via Twitter, Facebook, Google+, and on our main site: www.nmcompass.com

  • Media are welcome to contact us directly to request an interview with our managing editor and editor-in-chief regarding the project, police use of force in Albuquerque in general, and/or transparency, public records and FOIA issues.


CHALLENGES & FAQs


Are any of the materials (videos, photos, etc.) graphic? How will you be presenting those?


In general, we will be providing as much of the primary source material as possible. 

In some cases we may choose to detail the contents of a record without presenting the full file. We may also take action to protect the privacy of a victim and their family, including blurring video and/or obscuring audio when sensitive / identifying information appears.

Clear and relevant trigger warnings on our site regarding the contents of each record will also be present so members of the public are aware of what to expect when making the decision to view or not view the record.

We are also talking with the families of each shooting victim to explain the project and respond to concerns they might have about the materials.


Can I donate anonymously to the project?


Yes, absolutely. We understand that some people may choose to support the project anonymously. We will still deliver the rewards for each level of funding as appropriate.


What do you hope this project will achieve?


Our goal is for the project to provide a transparent look at some of the issues around use of force. We hope it will help foster a more productive, thoughtful conversation by all stakeholders about how and why excessive use of force occurs.

We also believe that by building the interactive database and reporting project in a transparent way, other journalism startups and local/regional news orgs will be able to use it as a model for their own efforts around this and similar topics. This will be an open source project, and we'll be providing access so that news orgs / developers can use the model.
story_txt:
Since 2010, Albuquerque police officers have been involved in dozens of shootings, many of them fatal. Millions of dollars in taxpayer money has been paid out by verdict and by settlement in civil lawsuits. A Department of Justice report released in April detailed a troubled and complex relationship between police officers, public officials, and residents of Albuquerque, particularly those facing a mental illness. The report (embedded below) described the problem as “a culture of aggression” and noted that leadership had failed to provide proper civilian / internal oversight, and training. The result: Albuquerque police officers too often use deadly force or near-deadly force inappropriately.We believe that access to public records and a serious look at each shooting is needed to reduce sensationalism around 
the topic, and encourage all stakeholders (including 
policymakers and law enforcement) to examine the “culture of 
aggression” outlined by the DOJ. OUR PROJECT:One of the most troubling issues suggested by the DOJ report is a lack of transparency.Police and city officials have been evasive and at times outright refused to provide information requested by city councilors/policymakers, journalists, and Albuquerque residents - including the families of those fatally shot by police officers.In part because of this lack of transparency, local, national and international news outlets have frequently focused on the most sensational aspects of the James Boyd case and other shootings. Media outlets have also been quick to draw conclusions that mischaracterize police, policymakers, shooting victims and their families, and Albuquerque's community at large. The New Mexico Compass requested and received public records 
related to over two dozen of the shootings from 2010 - present, 
including officers’ lapel cam footage and belt-tape audio recordings, 
along with witness interviews, reports and other materials.We will use funds raised via this campaign to:a)  Create a searchable, interactive database of public records around each fatal shooting (taking cues from models like ProPublica’s Dollars for Docs project, as well as the ChicagoCrime and Homicide Watch projects).Members of the community, policy makers, and local, regional and national journalists will be able to examine public records related to each specific shooting. Anyone is also welcome to suggest or contribute additional public records they have access to or are aware of.b)  Develop, report, and present comprehensive stories surrounding the fatal shooting cases we received public records for. c)  Provide a small stipend (around 25 percent of the total project cost) for our full time staff while we begin the process of raising a comprehensive operating budget. We believe this project will provide a model for transparency in data and storytelling, and we hope it will encourage other journalists and organizations to answer questions like these:“How does the public perceive journalism?”“How can journalists evolve to improve the level of public trust in the press?”“What does a more active, transparent and open-source flow of communication between the public and the press look like?”
ABOUT USEditor in Chief Marisa Demarco has been a journalist for more than a decade and a musician all her life. A native New Mexican, she is co-founder of the New Mexico Compass, and works at KUNM News producing radio reports on 89.9 FM. Demarco has worked at the Weekly Alibi, the Albuquerque Tribune and the Daily Lobo. Managing Editor Margaret Wright is a writer, editor, occasional photographer and proud New Mexican. Before diving into journalism full time, she taught refugee youth and immigrant adults, supervised a federally funded nonprofit program, and provided therapeutic case management for at-risk families. She is co-founder of the New Mexico Compass and former managing editor of Albuquerque’s alternative newsweekly, the Alibi.Deputy Director Joe Cardillo joined the New Mexico Compass after six years of operations, product, and marketing experience in both legacy and startup environments. He’s passionate about data, design, open access, rocanroll, anything science-y and thinking about how to become a better human. ABOUT THE NEW MEXICO COMPASS 

The New Mexico Compass is a nonprofit startup dedicated to transparent, open-access journalism.Combined with the educational efforts of its parent organization, the New Mexico Journalism Collaborative, the Compass strives to be a model for reporting that strengthens the community and contributes to a healthy journalism ecosystem.All content at the New Mexico Compass adheres to the Society of Professional Journalists Code of Ethics. Editors follow the Associated Press Stylebook. Our editorial process and output maintain a strict firewall against outside influences, particularly from funding sources. The Compass is also committed to organizational transparency. Complete financial reports are publicly accessible on our website. OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
If you aren't able to donate to the campaign, please share it with your contacts on social networks and via email. You can find us online via Twitter, Facebook, Google+, and on our main site: www.nmcompass.comMedia are welcome to contact us directly to request an interview with our managing editor and editor-in-chief regarding the project, police use of force in Albuquerque in general, and/or transparency, public records and FOIA issues. CHALLENGES & FAQsAre any of the materials (videos, photos, etc.) graphic? How will you be presenting those?In general, we will be providing as much of the primary source material as possible. In some cases we may choose to detail the contents of a 
record without presenting the full file. We may also take action to protect the privacy of a victim and their family, including blurring video and/or obscuring audio
 when sensitive / identifying information appears. Clear and relevant trigger warnings on our site regarding the contents of each 
record will also be present so members of the public are aware of what to expect when making the decision to view or not view the record. We are also talking with the families of each shooting victim to explain the project and respond to concerns they might have about the materials. Can I donate anonymously to the project?Yes, absolutely. We understand that some people may choose to support the project anonymously. We will still deliver the rewards for each level of funding as appropriate. What do you hope this project will achieve? Our goal is for the project to provide a transparent look at some of the issues around use of force. We hope it will help foster a more productive, thoughtful conversation by all stakeholders about how and why excessive use of force occurs. We also believe that by building the interactive database and reporting project in a transparent way, other journalism startups and local/regional news orgs will be able to use it as a model for their own efforts around this and similar topics. This will be an open source project, and we'll be providing access so that news orgs / developers can use the model.

story:
ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN:

Hello everyone, many children drop out of school or perform poorly in their education every year! These children face challenges in their education due to lack of adequate learning materials because of severe poverty of which many of us hear as a story but its a reality! I have dedicated my life in supporting poor and needy children in their education.I am  here to raise funds to empower them in their education here in kenya.
My campaign  will raise funds to help these children  in their education through provision  of learning materials they need for a effective learning. the funds will help buy and supply learning materials  like books, pens, pencils,clothes,food  and other materials needed for a child's learning in different schools.

 (samples of learning materials kids need)

Your generous contribution,will have high impact to the lives of these children in their education, hence a better,learned and Empowered society.



WHAT I NEED:

  I have a budget of $5000 this season, which i hope to raise in this campaign, the budget is shown below:
feeding program--------$1500
clothing (school uniforms)$1250
exercise books ----------$1000
writing pens --------------$600
transport ---------------------$400
pencils and rubbers-----$200
crayons,modelling paste-$150
----------------------------------------------
totals                                    $5000
-------------------------------------------------
To achieve this goal ,I have also created the perks you can claim one or more!  each perk have its description on how that money can support. help reach the goal!

THE IMPACT:

(kids will have meals,learning materials and good uniforms as above pictures!)

Contribute and make a change! touch the lives of these children in their world! this campaign will have adverse impact to the lives of 200 children! you might not be in contact with them but your contribution will affect their lives positively. we will cover the event with videos and photos which will be shared to those who will support this event. Please like our Facebook page provided below  to follow  our  future updates and events. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

You can participate on this campaign by sharing to your friends who can contribute through social  media.  I will highly appreciate your alternate support. thank you and God bless you,
                                                                                 PETER MAITHYA.
                                                                                 (campaign leader)

story:
About MYCincinnati

MYCincinnati (Music for Youth in Cincinnati) is a free, daily youth orchestra program for children in Price Hill. Our 80 students attend the program every weekday for two hours, learning violin, viola, cello, double bass, and playing in an orchestra. MYCincinnati’s mission is to use music as a vehicle for youth development and social change. Through the intense study of music within a supportive community, our young musicians learn to practice empathy, creativity, resilience, reflection, and collaboration – skills that will empower them to be the responsible leaders of the future. MYCincinnati is inspired by El Sistema, the revolutionary Venezuelan youth orchestra program that has inspired similar programs around the world.

MYCincinnati is a program of Price Hill Will, a non-profit 501(c)3 community development organization serving East, West, and Lower Price Hill. All contributions to MYCincinnati are tax-deductible, including those made to this campaign.

History

When MYCincinnati started in 2011, we didn't have much. 11 children, 2 teachers, borrowed instruments, a borrowed space, and little money. We've accomplished so much together in the last four and a half years:

  • We've increased enrollment from 11 to 80, added the Pre-Orchestra Program (K-2nd), and added elective classes in piano, guitar, flute, bucket drums, step dance, and art.
  • We moved into an amazing space: the historic firehouse on Warsaw Avenue.

  • Last summer, MYCincinnati's Orchestras performed side-by-side with the Chicago Metamorphosis Orchestra, conducted by John Morris Russell of the Cincinnati Pops.

  • Last spring, MYCincinnati's Ambassador Ensemble completed their yearlong social justice project, performing all around the city to huge audiences. This fall, the ensemble performed a sold-out concert with Swedish Grammy-nominated songwriter Jens Lekman.

  • Many of our students are studying privately with members of the Cincinnati Symphony, Cincinnati Chamber Orchestra, and three have successfully auditioned for Cincinnati's School for Creative and Performing Arts (SCPA).

  • We've collaborated with the Cincinnati Opera, Cincinnati Chamber Orchestra, Cincinnati Symphony, Cincinnati Boychoir, National Underground Railroad Freedom Center, Music Resource Center, and Contemporary Arts Center, and more.

From symphonies and choirs, to rappers and songwriters, MYCincinnati's young musicians are taking part in arts experiences that will expand their imaginations, inspire them to strive for excellence, and connect them to the amazing community of artists in Cincinnati.

What we need

MYCincinnati is a grassroots organization. We've learned how to make the very most out of every volunteer hour, every donated item, every dollar raised. Thanks to your support, we've grown tremendously since our founding in 2011. Still, we rely on our community for support and encouragement. We need your help to expand our reach and deepen our impact in the neighborhood. 

Your donation supports our incredible staff, who go above and beyond every single day. It also helps us purchase quality instruments, musical supplies, snacks, and pay our rent. Because Price Hill Will covers all overhead, 100% of your donation goes directly to MYCincinnati program costs.

Other ways to help

​Share our campaign on your Facebook page!

"Like" us on Facebook.

Follow us on Twitter.

Volunteer.

Link your Kroger card.

Visit our Website.

Visit our YouTube Channel.

Email Eddy at eddy@pricehillwill.org with questions or for more information.

Leadership

 

Eddy Kwon is a violinist, teacher, and composer-performer from Minneapolis, Minnesota. He received a BM in Jazz Studies from the University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music, where he was also a Cincinnatus Presidential Full Scholar. He has worked with El Sistema-inspired programs around the world, including those in Texas, Colombia, and South Korea. Eddy is a founding member of The Happy Maladies and is active in the Cincinnati creative arts community as a performer, curator, and composer. In 2014, he received the Art Ambassador Fellowship from the City of Cincinnati and was nominated for the United States Artists Fellowship. Eddy is founder and director of MYCincinnati's Ambassador Ensembles.

Josh Fink is a composer, teacher, and multi-instrumentalist based in Cincinnati, Ohio. He received his Bachelor of Music and Master of Music degrees from Northwestern University where he studied with Hans Jensen. Visit http://josh--fink.tumblr.com to hear his compositions, bands, and live performances.

                                                  

Carroll Wallace is a firm believer in the arts as a progressive and instrumental tool in society. She studied Art, English and Music (viola) in college and served as a Rural Health and Sanitation Volunteer in the United States Peace Corps. She loves people, art, research & development, sports, talking and laughing - and is excited to work with the fantastic MYCincinnati music program! [Se habla espanol].

                                                      

Annie Darlin Gordon is passionate about the cross-section between music education and social justice and all that music has to offer to the young mind. Annie earned her Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Flute Performance from the Oberlin Conservatory and Carnegie Mellon University, respectively. As a flutist, Annie loves performing all types of music related to the classical genre. Her recent performance milestones include appearances as second flute of Queen City Chamber Opera, substituting with the Pittsburgh Symphony, concerti with the Carnegie Mellon Contemporary Ensemble and the CMU All University Orchestra, and two summer seasons as the Contemporary Flute Fellow at the Aspen Music Festival.

                                                           

Laura Jekel (Founder and Advisor) was one of 10 people chosen to take part in the 2010-2011 Abreu Fellows Program, a training program through New England Conservatory that is helping to develop El Sistema-inspired programs in the United States. Originally from Boston, Laura has performed and taught throughout Latin America and the United States. Laura has studied at Carnegie Mellon University, where she completed her master of music degree, and at the Peabody Institute.

                       Thank you!

story:
Hello friends

my name is Rose Robin.

I help the children gain confidence in their abilities.

I help children have confidence in their communication skills with outsiders.

I'm filming a documentary seires to help promote the beautiful side of countries in central America.

Let me explian how.

 

I am currently traveling through Belize by bike, giving free art workshops in small rural villages an filming a documentary series called 'Loving Belize'. Please watch the episode above to get an idea of the work I do. I am filming episode 2 of 'Loving Belize' the episode above is from the documentary series I did in Mexico 'Mexico Encantador'.

I have been filming a free online documentary series about countries in Central America for the past year and a half. I believe the international media has given countries like Mexico and Belize a bad reputation by blowing the drug war out of proportion and things like pig flue and infected Mangos. I interview the man who had the mango farm the media pinpointed, he did not have infected mangos he was selling them to cheap to the US market, he is completely ruined now. Just like the Mango farmer the media is ruining many peoples lives and creating more poverty by scaring off the tourists.

So I film the beauty, tradition and culture this countries. I interview people from all walks of life to give the viewer an inside and personal experience through the documentary. I'm currently filming in Belize and I am discovering just how lovely the local people are.

The impact I make by giving art workshops in rural villages is one of helping the children gain confidence in their abilities, and because I am a foreigner the contact with me helps them have confidence in their communication skills with outsiders. Having the art workshops as part of each episode in the documentary series helps you to see all of the community for the oldest to and youngest, I've interview a man that was 106 years old for instance, It was beautiful to see how the community loved and respected him.

For other examples of my work you can see season 1& 2 of the documentary series in Mexico called 'Enchanting Mexico / México Encantador' on the none profit 'Painting Pirates' website:

By donating to this fundraiser you are making it possible to buy materials for the workshops and food for me to continue my work.
As I am biking and camping, and often I am invited to stay with families I met, I do not need a big budget to complete this project. As every thing I do is free, the workshops and the documentary series I do need help from kind hearted people who understand the problems I am dealing with.
I hope you see the good that this kind of work does, and you enjoy watching the episode above. It's with your help and your kind donation that I will be able to continue. 


As a perk for your donation, how ever much you can give, I will mention your name in the credits of the next episode as a donator to the cause.

If you don't have any money to spear, then you can help by spreading the news to your friends by email and Facebook. Please take the time to click that you like the project and visit me on my Facebook to see the work I am doing right now in Belize.

Thank you!

These are messages from the members of this project.

My name is Fidel Santoya

I am the vice principal of Sarteneja R.C. school. I am impressed with the work Miss Rose Robin does in educating and sharing her experience to support education through art work. I is amazing how my philosophy of art has changed with her I have learned that everybody is an artist and art is a way of expressing feeling and sentiments and sharing frustration and success. I would encourage you to become part of her success by giving monetary contribution to a worthy cause.

story:
To see a video of Dr. Wu lecturing, please click here. Check out the gallery for pictures.

 

Background

My name is Maegan Hodge, and I am a Chinese herbalist & licensed acupuncturist practicing in Richmond, Virginia.  

I graduated from the University of Virginia with a B.A. in psychology in 2003, I attended National College of Natural Medicine in Portland, Oregon where I developed profound respect for Eastern medicine, and received my Masters of Science in Oriental Medicine in 2011.    

An incredibly special education opportunity has now presented itself - Dr. Wu Sheng’an, one of China’s most distinguished medicine elders will systematically transmit his view of life and medicine, as well as his unique clinical approach to difficult and recalcitrant disorders to a small group of 25 students from around the world over a roughly 2 week span in late August/early September of this year.   

 

Impact

In a culture that predominately offers medical options that leave many with no answers, and no real way to get to the root of their health issues, being able to travel to China and bring these teachings home will literally benefit thousands of people over the course of my career as an Eastern medicine practitioner.  

I absolutely love that we can use these social funding sites to fund art and technology and band tours and business ventures - but just imagine what a powerful seed you are planting by funding this Mission to China.  What else could you donate your money towards that will have tangible, positive benefit in peope's lives every day for decades?  

 

To Make This Happen


Truly, I estimate this 2.5 week trip is going to cost about $5,000.  This will pay for my tuition, room & board ($3500) and flights ($1500 estimated).  
 
Even if I don't reach my fundraising goal, which is only part of the true need, the fund are still going towards the trip.  I'm going to manifest this goal no matter what!!
 

It's Only Natural To Wonder - What's In It For You?

You are welcome to either claim some Chinese Medicine treatment for yourself, or to donate it to those who demonstrate financial need.  All treatments shall be performed at our clinic in Richmond, Virginia.  All new patients will still be required to fill out all of our new patient paperwork, and will still be subject to our payment & cancellation policies.

 

Even If You Can't Donate

No hard feelings guys!  Times are tough out there.  You can be a huge help by spreading my campaing around a little.  Indiegogo has some of those really handy share tools - Facebook it, Twitter it, whatever.  Anything is hugely helpful.  Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

My name is Maegan Hodge, and I am a Chinese herbalist & licensed acupuncturist practicing in Richmond, Virginia.  
I graduated from the University of Virginia with a B.A. in psychology in 2003, I attended National College of Natural Medicine in Portland, Oregon where I developed profound respect for Eastern medicine, and received my Masters of Science in Oriental Medicine in 2011.    
An incredibly special education opportunity has now presented itself - Dr. Wu Sheng’an, one of China’s most distinguished medicine elders will systematically transmit his view of life and medicine, as well as his unique clinical approach to difficult and recalcitrant disorders to a small group of 25 students from around the world over a roughly 2 week span in late August/early September of this year.   
 
Impact
In a culture that predominately offers medical options that leave many with no answers, and no real way to get to the root of their health issues, being able to travel to China and bring these teachings home will literally benefit thousands of people over the course of my career as an Eastern medicine practitioner.  
I absolutely love that we can use these social funding sites to fund art and technology and band tours and business ventures - but just imagine what a powerful seed you are planting by funding this Mission to China.  What else could you donate your money towards that will have tangible, positive benefit in peope's lives every day for decades?  
 
To Make This Happen
Truly, I estimate this 2.5 week trip is going to cost about $5,000.  This will pay for my tuition, room & board ($3500) and flights ($1500 estimated).  
 
Even if I don't reach my fundraising goal, which is only part of the true need, the fund are still going towards the trip.  I'm going to manifest this goal no matter what!!
 
It's Only Natural To Wonder - What's In It For You?

You are welcome to either claim some Chinese Medicine treatment for yourself, or to donate it to those who demonstrate financial need.  All treatments shall be performed at our clinic in Richmond, Virginia.  All new patients will still be required to fill out all of our new patient paperwork, and will still be subject to our payment & cancellation policies.
 


Even If You Can't Donate
No hard feelings guys!  Times are tough out there.  You can be a huge help by spreading my campaing around a little.  Indiegogo has some of those really handy share tools - Facebook it, Twitter it, whatever.  Anything is hugely helpful.  Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

story:
Beijing Summer Course

 

Intro

Hello there, I'm Grant Clerehugh, I'm currently at University studying Chinese and Business Management. I first started learning Chinese in secondary school just out of interest, that was four years ago; and I have been interested in Chinese culture for much longer. Even though I have been learning for a while now I still haven't been to China, but this summer I have to go as part of my course requirement, I am SO excited about going as it's really going to progress my language ability so I can open up a chain of international language schools after I finish University. I won't be getting any funding from University, so I really need the support from all you lovely people.

 

The Breakdown

The educational trip will last 3 months and will cost £1,220 in total. Lessons will be £360(120 hours), Accommodation £300, Flights £500, Visa £60. I have been searching for months where the cheapest places are to live, and the cheapest courses are, so that I can go to Beijing for longer and enjoy more of the culture and exposure, every donation is wholeheartedly welcome and appreciated and puts me one step closer to my China dream that I have been waiting for, for four years.

This is the School I will be taking classes at (English option at top of page) - http://www.hengshuchinese.com/

Also see the perks list to see what your donations will get you in return. :)

 

What it means

I have, as I previously mentioned been planning this for months, but I have been dreaming about it for years, this educational summer trip will be an amazing experience and it will be my first time going to China, one of many I hope. So with your support I can get there at last and start to build the way to my future.

 

祝你们好健康

story:
Short Summary

  When I found out I was pregnant, I was elated and scared beyond belief.  My first pregnancy ended in great tragedy.  I was pregnant with twins, but due to complications I lost both boys.  I was devastated and depressed until the day I missed my cycle and thought, hoped, I was pregnant again.  This pregnancy was normal except for the fact that he was huge.  They induced labor, broke my water and had to suction him out.  The first time I saw Jacob, he was blue, he had rapid breathing and they immediately took him to the neonatal ICU.  After that, I didn't see him for three days.....I couldn't lose another baby.

      Once they brought him to me, I fell in love.  He was the best thing in my life and he was perfect. He went to bed on time, he never cried and everything was great until 18 months later.  He didn't talk and didn't make eye contact with anyone.  At first, we thought he might be deaf.  He didn't respond to "Jacob" or any other noises. The doctor said his hearing was fine. We took him to a behavioral physician who told us he was ADHD and perscribed ritalin. He became a zombie. The medicine seemed to suck the life out of him. Then, the physician perscribed prozac and he began banging his head against the walls.

     I decided from that point on, I didn't care what he had, he was not going to take anymore medicine.  After that, I decided to work with his teachers to try to help him in school.  Just about then, Autism awareness started to gain popularity. I started reading everything I could; and that lead me to UCSB, where they were doing research on Autism. They tested and observed him for hours and the diagnosis was Autism. They said he was high functioning due to the work I had done with him.  It was like an amazing weight was lifted off my shoulders, but now I had a new purpose.

    I had Jacob as well as my two younger girls, Katie and Becca and my kids were my love.  My second love was teaching. I was a teacher and I loved every minute of it.  I was a better teacher because of my son.  Until, while working at an underpriledged school in a "not so great" area, I contracted congestive heart failure and I haven't been able to work since.

    Though Jacob has Autism, he has taken to all art: drawing, clay, painting and fashion design.  He can do it all.  He started drawing before he could write.  Its like the space our brains use for  social conventions, interpersonal relationships or the 3 R's-reading, writing and arithmetic, his brain has filled with art.  He can sit and focus on a picture and he is in his own world and he is for, a moment, happy. With Autism comes so many challenges and when he is working on art he is at peace.  When you are a mother all you want for your child is peace and happiness, nothing more.

    My son turned 28 this year and got the guts to venture out. He applied to an art school.  Honestly it was a long shot, but I have learned with Jacob, anything is possible.  He interviewed, in his own awkward, complicated, innocent way, art in hand.  The admission reps seemed flabergasted .  My autistic son had shown them what Autism can do.  They accepted him. Again, this familiar feeling of elation and fear came back.  He could finally follow his dreams, but how could I afford it. 
  
  This is why I am starting this campaign.  If you invest your money in my son, you are helping fulfill his lifelong dream.  Not only that, but you are showing the world what a boy, no a man, with Autism can accomplish.

 

 

What We Need and What You Get

Funding

    Every bit of the funding will go to Jacob's schooling.  Yes, he is receivieng money from the government, but the amount they offered, isnt even enough to cover tuition.  We also need money for him to live in London (ie food, transportation, books, and housing) and money for him to fly over there. You can imagine how expensive a plane ride to London is. One of the biggest obstacles is the down payment.  We must have 2000 pounds, which is 3072.80 in U.S. dollars by August 31st, in order for them to keep a spot for him.  He also needs to purchase a Visa, so he can hopefully find some work.  He has never wanted anything for free, he wants to earn it, just like everyone else.

 

Perks

     The biggest perk to you, in helping my son Jacob, is that you will be starting the career of a soon to be great artist of this time. You would be able to say I knew Jacob when he was just getting his start.  If you like, he would love to treat you to a piece af art, all your own.

 

The Impact

   On a greater scale, you would not only be helping to benefit the art world, you would be benefitting the autistic world as well. Many have heard of Autism, but it is just a word.  They know nothing of its meaning or how it manifests. My son can show the world that Autism is not a disease, its a gift. Autistic people love, laugh and feel just like everyone else.  He should not be held back because of a diagnosis, both his and mine.  

    My son is truely a fantastic artist.  It is not only something he was meant to do, but something he loves with every fiber of his being.  By sharing your money with us, you would be forever changing the life of my wonderful, talented, loving son, Jacob.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

     Now,  I know many of you are in a similar situation as I am.  So, if you can only give a little or can't give at all,please spread the word to anyone you know.   Indiegogo has sharetools that can help, too

   If a few people can donate a few dollars, my son's entire life, and mine as well, will be better for it.  Thank you for your time!!!!!!!!
