story:
Who is She?


                  

The book "Are You In Inc: PR's Alter Ego" by Nicole Garner,  focuses on niche Public Relations and publicity disciplines of fashion, music, entertainment and film.  This complete manual is filled with everything one needs to know about the  world of PR equipped with very specific tools of the trade. 

To help spread the wealth of knowledge in this book Nicole and the "Are You In Inc Team" are setting out to create a multi-market book tour. Already being received greatly by Universities and professional conference around the nation, the "Are You In Inc" team understands that this powerful tool can not only inform but inspire and wants to touch as many people as possible.  

The tour will focus on methods of public relations and social media in 2013 and beyond, entrepreneurism, and tools that you may have not learned inside the classroom or on your current job that will give you an upper hand advantage. 



The Reason Behind It All?


                 


Be A Part Of Something Big! 

"If I was down to my last dollar, I would use it on PR" - Bill Gates

In today's world knowing and understanding PR is essential to business survival and brand longevity. Whether you are a student looking to help bring this tour to your campus, a professional organization looking to bring in a speaker on PR and Entrepreneurism, or just want to join in and help support a movement of dreams - here's a chance to fund what matters to you! 


What We Need & What You Get

The goal listed is the minimum need of  ($5,500 + Indiegogo fees) to make this book tour happen in all its awesomeness. Our goal is to go into TEN additional markets through out the rest of 2013 and the top of 2014.  We are offsetting many of the costs by being economically smart and fiscally fit but will need help with the remaining transportation, airfare, and lodging.  We believe words are powerful, so we are speaking this campaign into being fully funded! We have also provided a comfortable level at which any and everyone who wants to be a part of something big can.  


Our team has been working diligently researching organizations and locations to host the best and most impactful events and have already received confirmations of interest in bringing the tour to their markets.  Each stop of the tour will include a book signing, transparent q&a and a panel featuring local business professionals in each market. Depending on your level of donation, you can even bring the tour to your very own market. 

If this campaign gets overly funded, we plan to add more cities to the Tour! 


The Impact


                                    


The difference your contribution will make:

  • The "Are You In Inc" Book Tour will help to give insightful information on skills that are applicable to any industry 

  • For those looking to get into PR, or use PR in their everyday business lives - this book tour aims to not only inform but inspire


    “You are never too old to set another goal or to dream a new dream.”

    Inspire yourself or someone around you to set foot on the road to entrepreneurism 


    For the thinkers… the doers… the believers….become a part of something BIG  and  help bring this book tour to as many cities as possible! 


  • See what people are saying about the book and the tour stops so far! All we ask is that you trust and believe  - http://runninginheelstour.blogspot.com/

Other Ways You Can Help


                                


  • We would love for you to help us get the word out and become an ambassador for the campaign! Here are few ways on how: 
  • Share this campaign link on your social media sites igg.me/at/areyouininc 
  • Share the full length version of the video and the campaign link with your group, list, or organization - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1pqgW9K6Y7o&feature=c4-overview-vl&list=PLEFF1F7C97EA77049
  • Use the hashtag #AreYouInInc in your postings
  • Join our mailing list at www.areyouininc.com to learn more on "Are You In Inc" Campaign Contributor Perks
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!


XOXO,

Nicole Garner and the "Are You In Inc" Team 


REMEMBER TO LEAVE YOUR SOCIAL MEDIA HANDLERS, SO WE CAN SING PRAISES FOR YOUR DONATIONS!

story:
Tales from the Slums

Tales from the Slums is an educational project that aims to provide FREE education to kids from Kibera District, Nairobi, Kenya. We are a group of people with social awareness and worried about the donation's system problems with lack of sustainability and empowerment.

We aim for a better world, and we believe our dream can be achieved through education. Our campaign is created to raise awareness for our solution, that is, providing FREE education to all kids from the slums in a sustainable way BY the community TO the community.

We, hereby, kick off with Kibera District, which is considered as the largest slum in Nairobi and largest urban slum in Africa [1]. Our pivot campaign includes two people (a teacher and a designer) assisting ten students (e.g., 10-18 years old) to collaboratively write an e-book on a topic they desire. The income from the sales of the book will create a chance to buy new materials, motivate and educate new students to actively collaborate in this project for the next phases.

Tales from the Slums provides tools, knowledge and seed funding for creating, designing, publishing and selling content from the kids of the slums through e-books.

Your help is needed!

We need funding for starting the first pivoting to cover the tickets, rent, salary, living expenses.

Remember, only the King of the Slums will get a signed version of the printed book from the authors.

Our activities and money raised can be tracked and monitored via our website:

http://talesfromslums.tk/

Why are we different than the others?

We believe that making donations is NOT the right solution for a sustainable benefit. Therefore, we are different than the other campaigns in these aspects:

  • We do NOT donate money just for its sake,
  • We support education and empower slum communities.
  • We provide social benefits to the kids from the slums
  • We use technology (e.g., e-books, computer workshops)
  • We are transparent
  • We aim to build a process that can be replicated to other slums!

How can you help us?

If we can't raise enough funds for our campaign, our project won't happen. So, help us make it HAPPEN by:

  • SHARING this with the people who might be interested and everyone else,
  • VOLUNTEERING with our organization.
  • Be EARLY supporter by pre-buying the very first eBook. 
  • GIVING us more ideas via talesfromtheslums@gmail.com,

[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kibera

story:
About Us:

WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT IN HELPING US FUND OUR PRODUCTION TO END BULLYING! IT COULD BE YOUR CHILD WHO NEEDS TO SEE THIS PLAY!

Imagine being the parent of a child who commits suicide because they are bullied 'to death' due to their race, sexuality, body type, social status, learning ability, etc. Help us change the lives of your children!

We are an edutainment organization stationed in Montgomery, Alabama. Southern Soul Performing Education Association (SSPEA) is comprised of EDUCATORS, directors, and performers committed to producing life altering performances. It is the mission of this collective to reach EVERY child in the world, one performance at a time.


Bullying and the lack of positive self-esteem and self love are an epidemic in our youth.


SSPEA strives to produce innovative live theater, film, musical productions, camps, seminars, and workshops with impactful messages that transcend any particular gender, race, class or culture. They simply want to speak to the HUMAN experience by tapping into the emotions that foster introspection and positive change. With the primary focus being to serve as the village that assists in instilling knowledge, wisdom, morals and values in today’s youth, this group has worked hard to create a production that will lead to a generation of socially conscience and productive citizens.

"This Skin I'm In" is a production aimed at beating down the statistics related to the casualties of bullying and low self esteem. As the producers of this production, we have been bullied and we have bullied, and for that reason we are dedicated to ending the cycle.

 What We Need & What You Get:

  • The funds we are seeking for this project will go towards our mission to put this play in front of every child we can. Your financial blessing will fund the following:

    1. Copyrights and licenses

    2. Set contruction and materials

    3. Costumes and props

    4. Rehearsal fees

    5. Travel expenses

    6. Marketing/Promotions

    7. Correspondence duplication

    8. Actors fees

    9. Technical staff

  • Every contributor is special to us, and every dollar matters. Here's what your support will get you.

    1. The ability to say, "I helped to end bullying and promote self love"

    2. EVERY individual who contributes will be listed as a supporter on our organization's website (unless they request anonymity).

    3. A contribution of at least $100.00 will earn a special limited edition t-shirt in support of anti-bullying.

    4. Higher level contributions come with a complete package of paraphernalia and gifts along with marketing and promotional opportunities.  (Full package details available by emailing SouthernSoulEducators@gmail.com)

    5. Additional perks to come!

In the event that we do not reach our goal of 15,000.00, we will use the funds raised to put a dent in as much of our production costs as possible.  We never stop producing quality edutainment and we have a season of performances we will be producing for 2012-2013.

The Impact:

WE ARE THE CHANGE WE WOULD LIKE TO SEE! We teach through performance and we mentor through our daily lives.

Other Ways You Can Help:

We understand that you may not have the financial resources to assist us.  If that is the case then your support by donating items, your time, attending our events, and most important, spreading the word about our organization is just as important and necessary for our efforts.  We love and appreciate you for the considersation. Please stay connected to us.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Wendy Miller and I moved to Belize in January 2012.  I am a real estate agent here and during the course of my daily interactions I have come to meet and know several bright young individuals who just need a break. 

During my time here I have learned a few things about Belize, including how the education is funded.  I feel strongly about the power of education, especially in the education of young women.  It has been documented in countries around the world that education of the young women goes a long way to improving the lives of the community in which they live.

For now I would like to set up a campaign to help one young lady in Punta Gorda.  Her name is Jennifer and she is a young Maya lady.  Her parents are able to pay the tuition for her first year in high school but they are not able to pay for the textbooks, her writing materials, her uniform including shoes and socks.  This young lady wants to go on and either become a teacher or a nurse and it breaks my heart that she may not have the opportunity to follow her dream due to financial constraints, that we in North America take for granted - to be able to go to high school.

Our contributions will help Jennifer towards her goal of continuing her education and the goal stated above is to provide funds for her for each year of high school.  She will be moving to another city in Belize, away from her parents, in order to get assistance with doing her homework.  This is a sacrifice that Jennifer and her parents have already agreed to so that she may continue her education.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The average cost for one year of high school is $500 USD, which includes tuition, textbooks, paper, pens, pencils, school uniform including socks and shoes.

The goal of this drive is to raise whatever funds we can.  The entire amount raised will be used to help Jennifer with her goal and if there are additional funds, other young ladies will be helped, as yet unnamed.

The Impact

Belize, as a country, is still quite young, having reached full independence from the British on September 21, 1981.  This puts this country in its infancy still, trying to sort things out, to figure out how to make their way, after being under British rule since 1862.   The country has many objectives to meet, fully funded education being one of them, and until such time that this happens, we can show our support by providing assistance to the people who are quite deserving but because of financial circumstances, and often times gender, are unable to take advantage of higher education.

According to http://www.right-to-education.org/node/187, education of the females in a society leads "directly to better reproductive health,  improved family health, economic growth, for the family and for society, as well as lower rates of child mortality and malnutrition. It is also key in the fight against the spread of HIV & AIDS."

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to assist financially, please feel free to share this link to others.  Share on facebook, through email, twitter, and whatever other social media tools you may use.

Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!  Make it easy on yourself.

story:
Kids at Risk

Cambodia is a tough place to be a kid. Decades of conflict, displacement and unspeakable violence have shredded the services and protections that are supposed to help keep children safe. Thousands of families are living in extreme poverty in the toughest slums of the capital Phnom Penh, many of them having lost their farms and land.

Few of the children attend school. Many are runaways and orphans living on the street who are lured into gangs, crime and drug abuse. Many are HIV-positive. And many fall victim to trafficking, abuse and sexual exploitation at the hands of adult predators.

What we are doing about it

PROTECT (a program of Global Humanitaria) has been working in Cambodia for 10 years, helping to rescue kids from the hands of sexual predators, providing shelter, medical care and legal assistance, and finding safe homes for them where they can begin to rebuild their lives. PROTECT works in the following ways:

PREVENTION OF CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE THROUGH EDUCATION IN THE STREETS

PREVENTION THROUGH THE CONSTRUCTION OF SHELTERS FOR VULNERABLE CHILDREN


CARE AND SUPPORT TO VICTIMS THROUGH THE RECOVERY PROCESS


ASSISTING LAW ENFORCEMENT TO HELP BRING OFFENDER TO JUSTICE


Join Ami James and become a PROTECTOR


Tattoo artist Ami James, of New York Ink and Miami Ink, has become a Protector joining Global Humanitaria in the fight against child sexual exploitation. You can become a Protector, too. Help us build the "Bunni and Som House" in Andong, Cambodia. This shelter is dedicated to two of the child victims rescued by Global Humanitaria's Protect team in Cambodia, and will help provide safe alternatives to children and teens who might otherwise fall victim to sexual abuse and exploitation.

Our current shelter can only accommodate 29 children. In one small building; 13 girls share 4 beds. The walls and roof are made of corrugated metal, which traps the tropical heat and makes the buildings extremely uncomfortable.


THIS IS THE DINING AREA


We need to do More

Help us raise $45,000 to build a bigger, better shelter.

This beautiful new building will include 8 dormitory bedrooms (4 for boys and 4 for girls), 4 bathrooms, plus a kitchen, a library and office space for staff and operations. No more dark, cramped, stuffy rooms with beds crammed wall to wall. No more lean-to-kitchen. No more open-air classrooms.



What your dollars will provide

$10 buys 200 bricks

$50 buys 10 doors

$100 buys a case of wall tiles

$250 pays teachers’ salaries for a month

$500 buys 100 bags of cement

$1,000 buys the entire plumbing system

$2,000 buys 2,500 roof tiles


Our Progress so Far

650 children rescued

6000 children received preventive education

276 predators arrested

186 offenders convicted and sentenced

Other Ways You Can Help

Contribute to The Protect Project, any amount gets us closer to finishing a home for 29 children. Join the Ami James Protects Campaign and Become a Protector now!

Share our campaign with everyone you know!  Feel free to repost on Facebook and Twitter. Help us raise the money to build Bunni and Som's House, and help provide vulnerable street children with a safe, healthy, supportive home.

story:
Life Transitions Academy will be distributing the Accounting You Can Understand video FREE to all high school teachers upon request to assist in the real-world education of future business leaders, our youth.

Your Contribution Will

  • Impact the education of thousands of students via our high school outreach
  • Help the next generation become more successful entrepreneurs and decision makers
  • Complete the production of the Accounting You Can Understand video
  • Set up an interactive website to distribute educational material
  • Establish an effective social media outreach
  • Earn our appreciation as a person who cares about future leaders
  • Provide you with a tax deductible donation (Consult with your tax advisor)

 

Whether you love or hate accounting, there is no denial that understanding it is critical to making consistently good business decisions. Many people might equate reading an accounting book to walking on hot sand in your bare feet or having a tooth pulled and thus avoid even the thought of it. The Accounting You Can Understand video project exists to change that paradigm.   

The Accounting You Can Understand video is designed to provide the user with a concise presentation of the fundamental principles of the accounting system in a new and entertaining way. A good understanding of these principles establishes a solid foundation on which expanded accounting concepts and better decision making can be built. The completed video will be approximately forty minutes in length and will explore the basic foundation blocks of Luca Pacioli’s original accounting system developed in 1486 and demonstrate its presence in 21st Century systems. The video will reveal a simple logical path to recording transactions, emphasizing the “why” and not just the “how”.

A little know fact is that Luca Pacioli was a brilliant mathematician who as a monk became a mentor to the great Leonardo DaVinci. In fact he is credited with teaching Leonardo how to use proportional mathematics in his artwork. It is a technique that is very evident in his famous painting of the Last Supper.

Please help us by spreading the word about our project

 Use the Indiegogo Tools

story:
What is Yiddish Farm?

Yiddish Farm is a combination of a language school, an organic farm and an intentional community all in one. Our goal is to empower Jews to reclaim Yiddish as a living language and a source of Jewish identity.

 

What do we need?

We need to raise $15,000 to finish building a pole barn. This barn will be used to store produce and machinery as well as a wonderful programming space. This wil help our organization become more financially sustainable in the coming years.

The Prizes!*

  • $36 receives a custom-printed Yiddish Farm bencher with traditional zemiros as well as Yiddish songs.
  • $72 receives the above prize + a Yiddish Farm T-shirt
  • $108 receives all of the above + a basket of fresh garlic and garlic scape pesto
  • $180 receives all of the above + a kosher-slaughtered pasture-raised chicken from the farm.
  • $360 receives all of the above + a kosher-slaughtered pasture raised goose from the farm.
  • $1,800 receives all of the above + an inscription on the barn.

*Prizes must be claimed at the farm or in New York City.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this fundraiser on facebook or hang up flyers.

story:
Pay it forward – Get Sania to Australia to go to High School

Do you want to feel warm and fuzzy? Want to have no retail regret? Want to know you have done something amazing for someone who deserves it? Want to give a leg up to someone that needs it?

Well then help us crowd fund to get Sania to Australia to get the best education and see her on her way to her big dream of being a doctor.

Why does Sania want to be a doctor?
Sania has grown up in poverty, civil unrest, and persecution. She wants to become a person that can help the less fortunate instead of being the less fortunate person. The helpless person. Sania has seen more than a child should. She also wants to show them all that a girl can be educated and do anything!


Sania with her sister at their uncle's wedding back in 2007. before things got dangerous and scary.


Background

Sania and her family had to flee their home and are seeking refuge in Malaysia. Although they are now safe Sania has lost a lot of time in schooling (her parents had to take her out of school 3 years ago as there were fatal bombings targeting her school – female education is not really accepted). She only got back to school late last year when they settled into Malaysia. Due to the Malaysian public school system she was put into the grade for her age not her schooling level. Sania has gone from only knowing "Thank you" in Malay to being able to converse with her teachers and fellow students, writing is still quite difficult – Malay is a hard language to learn. Sania did top her class in English and did quite well in Science and Maths (the only two other subjects taught in English). Sania has done so well catching up as well as learning Malay, but if she continues this way she will never be able to continue into further studies, college and university, and will not be able to break the cycle of poverty let alone achieve her dream job – a doctor.



This is the children at the Science Centre in Kuala Lumpur. I got to take them when I was in Malaysia last year - a very special and rare treat.


Where do I fit in
I happen to be in the wrong place at the wrong time... very very wrong time. Sania’s parents, grandparents and uncle risked their lives – very literally – to ensure my safety. They not only put themselves in danger to get me to safety but forever more if the wrong people found out that they helped me and they didn’t even question it or pause. I am only here because they helped. People like that are rare. Now they need help and I want to do all I can... and you can help!

I have been told I should write a book but my PTSD has stopped me – if I can write the book everyone that donates will get an electronic copy for free.

Where will the money go
The biggest cost will be school fees (International State School Program) and homestay fees, and then there is student health insurance, Homestay placement fee, flights, uniforms, books, etc.

If the full amount is not reached all the raised money will go to tutors in Malaysia for Sania and her younger sisters Farwa and Sahar to help them get the best out of the education they can get in Malaysia.

Nitty Gritty break down of costs

Tuition Fees per annum     $13,632

Homestay fees per annum    $13,208 (per week $254)

Homestay Placement Fee one off    $220

Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) per annum   $507
(These prices are subject to change in 2014)
Click here to see all the details

Visa application fee  $535

Additional applicant charge for under 18  $135
Click here to see the visa details

Flights  ~$700 (this is subject to change)

Uniform  ~$205

Total    $29,142


Other Ways You Can Help
Your voice is powerful. Please tell your friends about this campaign. Post this campaign on Facebook! Tweet about it! We are so grateful for everything you do to get the word out about this campaign. Lets make Sania a doctor.

story:
Short Summary

Hi.  My name is Christine King and I am the founder of MySupervisorOnline which is a website (at beta stage) to support postgraduate students globally who are experiencing inadequate supervision, isolation and limited finances. 

After being a postgraduate student and then a postgraduate supervisor myself for over 10 years I have first hand experience of the difficulties facing these students.  Here are some frightening statistics globally:

  • Between 30-60% of postgraduate students drop out in their first year
  • Of those that survive the first year, only 50% complete their degree
  • If a student completes only 30% will do it in the time originally allocated

To add to this:

  • 90% of the constraints to students completing are social (and not to do with the actual content of their thesis)
  • 80% of students are dissatisfied with their current supervision and/or academic supervisor
  • 72% of students experience some form of isolation

Being frustrated with these statistics and also being embedded in the system that made it difficult to change these statistics, I left the University to develop MySupervisorOnline.com. 

When I first started talking about the ideas behind MySupervisorOnline, I found something quite extraordinary.  Every person I spoke to either experienced difficulties themselves or knew at least one person who had difficulties within the current University system and/or their supervisor/advisor.  This led to students being completely demotivated or demoralised, rather than being enabled to reach their potential as researchers who should be focusing on trying to solve real world problems facing society today.

Being convinced of the problem, and then doing extensive market research with postgraduate students representing 18 different countries, our initial prototype was built.  The site we have today is not too different and has a range of functions to help students network, search for students across the globe doing similar research, develop research communities, and access a range of resources, including independent supervision.  (No more waiting for 3 months to get feedback on that thesis chapter!)

What We Need & What You Get

When I first developed the site we had a $100 registration fee to cover website development and maintenance costs but we soon realised that postgraduate students from developing countries could not afford this.  I did a test for 4 weeks using a $1 google ad to see the interest in our website and in this time we had 5000 students visit the site from every country you can think of (the top 5 countries were Ethiopia, Pakistan, India, Ghana and Cambodia).  The downside is that the majority were from developing countries asking to register but saying that they could not afford to.  (Compare our $100 registration with the average annual salary of $900 in Ethiopia)  This presented us with a challenge and while experts in the business field advised us to forget about these students and just concentrate on those that could pay, we were determined to ensure access to everyone.

This is where you come in.  To bring on students from developing countries under our new freemium model we need to make significant changes to our website as well as provide some moderator/supervisory support when they become a member.  The changes we need to make to our website include database changes for the new freemium model, integrating a crowdfunding platform so that these students can raise funds for their research expenses like buying a textbook or conducting their field work, as well as building a new supervisor portal from scratch.  Under the premium membership students have access to a whole range of additional resources including direct supervision with real independent supervisors.  To do all of these things we need some extra funds.  Here is how our funds will be used: 

  • The first $44,000 (our goal) goes directly to IT costs.  Our site has to be modified substantially to include these new changes and make it accessible to everyone.  We currently have 2 main platforms and we need 2 more - a Freelance/LinkedIn style platform for students to access supervisors and a crowdfunding platform to access funding.
  • The next $6,000 will go directly to additional resources for students on the site to support the use of these platforms as some of our features will be new to these students.
  • Any additional funds we raise will go directly toward providing students with our premium registration from countries such as Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Cambodia.

For every supporter that pledges $50 or over, we will provide a postgraduate student a premium registration.  This is our perk.  It is a 'feel good' perk and all we can afford.  Our premium membership includes search functions to find students doing similar research across the globe (enabling them to move research forward rather than duplicate it!), private and group chats in our virtual cafe, supervisor facilitated forums, research group function, research methods and tools database, resources database (videos, blogs), thesis management tools, access to FundMyThesis (for funding textbooks, conferences and fieldwork) and access to supervisors database, as well as selected e-books and webinars. 

So that you know this has gone toward a 'real' student's registration, you will be provided with the profile (name, photo etc.) of the student you support from our database which you can put on your fridge or on your desk, so that you know you have contributed to improving someone's chance of completing their degree.  You can also nominate a student, discipine, country or University with your pledge.

This means if we raise $50 000 then we will provide support to 1000 students across the globe ... and for every $50 more we raise, we will keep adding an extra student (at half price).  MySupervisorOnline is not making a profit in this process - we are dedicated to setting up a system that supports students globally and every dollar raised goes toward website changes or resources for students in lesser developed countries.

The Impact

Our Website has the potential to change the world.  In fact, when people see what we are really doing they see that we can change the entire student experience in postgraduate education and research.  Imagine if we could enhance completion rates by just 1%. Think about these few things in terms of how we can change the world just by helping students complete on time and with less pain:

  • Funding bodies spend tens of thousands of dollars each year on extravagant University fees and a stipend for students with no guarantee of completion
  • Some Universities get paid by governments when a student completes.  A University might invest in a student for 3 years and then they pull out of their degree
  • Some Universities are paid by the student directly and don't care how long it takes a student to complete.  The longer a student takes, the more money it is for them (ie. there is no motivation to improve supervision standards or address these issues)
  • International students spend years away from their families and often go back home with a debt that is often passed from generation to generation.  The longer it takes them to complete the more debt they incur.
  • In western countries there ia a high divorce rate and increased anti-depressant use as a result of students doing PhD's.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell as many people about us as you can and and send this around your social networks.  MySupervisorOnline is currently in an accelerator program, having been chosen in the top 10 out of a Global pool of IT companies, to launch it to success.  Our sponsors in this program believe we can change the world and we do to!  The more you can support us and the more you tell people about us, the more we can raise funds to bring students into the network, and bring in investors who can help us bring on board some more team members to support more students.

If you have had difficulties with your own supervision or advisors, or you know someone who has had difficulties trying to just get through their degree - please support us.  Your pledge will highlight to others how much of a need there is to find  solutions to this global problem.

Don't forget the Indiegogo share tools!

For those of you who are not familiar with the term Perk - where it says for example a Perk for $50 - this just means when you donate $50 you get the reward described.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi.  My name is Christine King and I am the founder of MySupervisorOnline which is a website (at beta stage) to support postgraduate students globally who are experiencing inadequate supervision, isolation and limited finances. 
After being a postgraduate student and then a postgraduate supervisor myself for over 10 years I have first hand experience of the difficulties facing these students.  Here are some frightening statistics globally:

Between 30-60% of postgraduate students drop out in their first year
Of those that survive the first year, only 50% complete their degree
If a student completes only 30% will do it in the time originally allocated

To add to this:

90% of the constraints to students completing are social (and not to do with the actual content of their thesis)
80% of students are dissatisfied with their current supervision and/or academic supervisor
72% of students experience some form of isolation

Being frustrated with these statistics and also being embedded in the system that made it difficult to change these statistics, I left the University to develop MySupervisorOnline.com. 
When I first started talking about the ideas behind MySupervisorOnline, I found something quite extraordinary.  Every person I spoke to either experienced difficulties themselves or knew at least one person who had difficulties within the current University system and/or their supervisor/advisor.  This led to students being completely demotivated or demoralised, rather than being enabled to reach their potential as researchers who should be focusing on trying to solve real world problems facing society today.
Being convinced of the problem, and then doing extensive market research with postgraduate students representing 18 different countries, our initial prototype was built.  The site we have today is not too different and has a range of functions to help students network, search for students across the globe doing similar research, develop research communities, and access a range of resources, including independent supervision.  (No more waiting for 3 months to get feedback on that thesis chapter!)


What We Need & What You Get
When I first developed the site we had a $100 registration fee to cover website development and maintenance costs but we soon realised that postgraduate students from developing countries could not afford this.  I did a test for 4 weeks using a $1 google ad to see the interest in our website and in this time we had 5000 students visit the site from every country you can think of (the top 5 countries were Ethiopia, Pakistan, India, Ghana and Cambodia).  The downside is that the majority were from developing countries asking to register but saying that they could not afford to.  (Compare our $100 registration with the average annual salary of $900 in Ethiopia)  This presented us with a challenge and while experts in the business field advised us to forget about these students and just concentrate on those that could pay, we were determined to ensure access to everyone.
This is where you come in.  To bring on students from developing countries under our new freemium model we need to make significant changes to our website as well as provide some moderator/supervisory support when they become a member.  The changes we need to make to our website include database changes for the new freemium model, integrating a crowdfunding platform so that these students can raise funds for their research expenses like buying a textbook or conducting their field work, as well as building a new supervisor portal from scratch.  Under the premium membership students have access to a whole range of additional resources including direct supervision with real independent supervisors.  To do all of these things we need some extra funds.  Here is how our funds will be used: 

The first $44,000 (our goal) goes directly to IT costs.  Our site has to be modified substantially to include these new changes and make it accessible to everyone.  We currently have 2 main platforms and we need 2 more - a Freelance/LinkedIn style platform for students to access supervisors and a crowdfunding platform to access funding.
The next $6,000 will go directly to additional resources for students on the site to support the use of these platforms as some of our features will be new to these students.
Any additional funds we raise will go directly toward providing students with our premium registration from countries such as Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Cambodia.

For every supporter that pledges $50 or over, we will provide a postgraduate student a premium registration.  This is our perk.  It is a 'feel good' perk and all we can afford.  Our premium membership includes search functions to find students doing similar research across the globe (enabling them to move research forward rather than duplicate it!), private and group chats in our virtual cafe, supervisor facilitated forums, research group function, research methods and tools database, resources database (videos, blogs), thesis management tools, access to FundMyThesis (for funding textbooks, conferences and fieldwork) and access to supervisors database, as well as selected e-books and webinars. 
So that you know this has gone toward a 'real' student's registration, you will be provided with the profile (name, photo etc.) of the student you support from our database which you can put on your fridge or on your desk, so that you know you have contributed to improving someone's chance of completing their degree.  You can also nominate a student, discipine, country or University with your pledge.
This means if we raise $50 000 then we will provide support to 1000 students across the globe ... and for every $50 more we raise, we will keep adding an extra student (at half price).  MySupervisorOnline is not making a profit in this process - we are dedicated to setting up a system that supports students globally and every dollar raised goes toward website changes or resources for students in lesser developed countries.

The Impact
Our Website has the potential to change the world.  In fact, when people see what we are really doing they see that we can change the entire student experience in postgraduate education and research.  Imagine if we could enhance completion rates by just 1%. Think about these few things in terms of how we can change the world just by helping students complete on time and with less pain:

Funding bodies spend tens of thousands of dollars each year on extravagant University fees and a stipend for students with no guarantee of completion
Some Universities get paid by governments when a student completes.  A University might invest in a student for 3 years and then they pull out of their degree
Some Universities are paid by the student directly and don't care how long it takes a student to complete.  The longer a student takes, the more money it is for them (ie. there is no motivation to improve supervision standards or address these issues)
International students spend years away from their families and often go back home with a debt that is often passed from generation to generation.  The longer it takes them to complete the more debt they incur.
In western countries there ia a high divorce rate and increased anti-depressant use as a result of students doing PhD's.

Other Ways You Can Help
Tell as many people about us as you can and and send this around your social networks.  MySupervisorOnline is currently in an accelerator program, having been chosen in the top 10 out of a Global pool of IT companies, to launch it to success.  Our sponsors in this program believe we can change the world and we do to!  The more you can support us and the more you tell people about us, the more we can raise funds to bring students into the network, and bring in investors who can help us bring on board some more team members to support more students.
If you have had difficulties with your own supervision or advisors, or you know someone who has had difficulties trying to just get through their degree - please support us.  Your pledge will highlight to others how much of a need there is to find  solutions to this global problem.
Don't forget the Indiegogo share tools!
For those of you who are not familiar with the term Perk - where it says for example a Perk for $50 - this just means when you donate $50 you get the reward described.

story:
Why we’re here.

Philadelphia school district has undergone extreme budget cuts, and arts programs have been removed from the curriculum. Students in Philadelphia are no longer exposed to the creativity, exploration of individuality, and critical thinking they experienced through the arts.

We will offer one month of free art classes for Philadelphia high school students in an effort to supplement this deficit of arts education. Students will be exposed to the works, careers, and techniques of prominent local artists, including:

  • Justin Tyner
  • Conrad Benner
  • Mike Smith
  • Todd Marrone
  • Jason Andrew Turner


Who we are.

Miss Mac Art Class is a rotating cast of artists and activists with a vested interest in the future of art education. We believe that creatively engaged and culturally exposed youth are better equipped to shape their own futures.

The program unites high school students and artists in the community to create an art show—an exhibition to raise funds for creating and maintaining art education programs in the city.

Philadelphia is the pilot, but we intend to make this a full time program. There is universal disappointment with the lack of public school funding for art education across the country.  We will become mobile—bringing similar art education programs to 12 cities a year, or more. In so doing, we will raise money for local organizations that continue to support the arts in their communities.


What we need.

Art Supplies. We will provide each student with two canvases, a sketchbook, and drawing supplies.  There will also be communal supplies, including paints, brushes, markers, and more.

Location. We have an amazing warehouse space for the month of November, but our overhead includes a security deposit, rent, utilities, and furniture rentals—tables and chairs for the students and instructors.

Business. We need to file for non-profit status, and it takes money to do good by others. There's also insurance, advertising, websites, salaries, and all the fun start-up costs.


How you can help.

Like us on Facebook.

Follow us on Instagram and Twitter.

Please donate.  Pick one of our great perks, like these snazzy buttons courtesy of John Steck, Jr.

Finally, if you're an artist and you’d like to participate, please contact us. We’d love to work with you. 

missmacartclass@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Brittany Shaffer, and I'll be a junior at Milligan College this fall, studying Business and Communications. I started College Junction, because as a student myself, I found that I had a lot of questions about college and wanted to make the most of those four years. I am creating this site to help students find answers to their college questions, enjoy their college years, and be prepared to get a job when they graduate. College Junction is entirely free to students. We just make money by ads on the site and affiliate links!
  • I am raising this money for College Junction, because we need to get some better photos for the site, do some web site improvement, and promote the site. 
  • By funding, you'll be helping me make an incredible resource for students to use that will help them: 1) Make it through college without going broke, 2) Enjoy the "best 4 years of their life", 3) Be prepared to get a job after they graduate.

 

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $500, which I plan to use to obtain better photos for the site, improve the site design and content, and promote the site to expand the audience. 

The perks vary, depending on how much you'd like to donate. You can receive something like being listed on the site as a funder (we'll include a link to your website!). Or you could receive a promotion of your product/website on one or more of College Junction's pages.

Even if we don't make $500, we can use any amount of money that we do make to start reaching our goals, they just won't necessarily go as far.

The Impact

This is a great project for you to invest in if you have had any interaction with college students or if you have a passion for that age group. College is a difficult time in one's life- it's a lot of change, growing up, and big decisions. My goal is for College Junction to make that a little bit easier and more fun for students, by helping them save money, enjoy life at college, and to prepare for after college.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate money, we can still your use help!

  • Tell students about the site! It's live and full of resources now, we're just wanting to make it even better!
  • Visit the site : college-junction.com . Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and check us out on Pinterest and YouTube!
  • Share this project with other people who might be interested in funding!

story:
UPDATE: Hey everybody! As you can see, we've hit our fundraising goal of $700 in one week! Hooray! Of course, the more donations we get, the more we can spread the book-love around Oberlin and beyond, so please keep spreading the word and contributing to our campaign. We can use donations beyond our initial goal to build our inventory, fund bigger and better events, and sponsor teach-ins and workshops. Additional donations will allow SWAP to go above and beyond operational expenses to provide for the Oberlin community in bigger and better ways. Many thanks to those who have donated their time and resources to help us reach our goal--now let's see how much more we can do together in the last 2 weeks of our campaign! This is just the beginning!

Who we are

We, Evan Cameron, Pablo Cerdera, Sarah Johnson, Jackson Kusiak, Joe Martin, Sophia (Zo) Paul, Dan Quigley, Silvia Sheffield, and Devon Wells, are the founding management team of SWAP: The Oberlin Book Co-op. We’re all students at Oberlin College, and we’ve all held leadership roles in other cooperatives. Collectively we have have a rich knowledge base and skill set that includes library science; web/database development; community organizing, education, and outreach; event planning; consensus; facilitation; coalition building; and budget balancing.

 

Why Oberlin needs a book co-op

As students, we were frustrated by the options that we had for getting books for classes. Too many students are forced to buy expensive textbooks to use for a semester, and then are getting scammed into selling them back to the big corporation-owned campus bookstore for a fraction of their true value. We saw the need to create an organization that would provide a more economical and sustainable way for students to get their textbooks and create a community space for the exchange of knowledge. We want SWAP to act as a support system for education inside and outside of the academy, and hope to use our space to facilitate skillshares and knowledge exchanges.

 

What we’ve already done

During the spring of 2013 we developed the framework of how the co-op will function. Our mission is to make knowledge free and accessible by creating and sustaining a cooperative to exchange, share, and recycle books, and to do so democratically, sustainably, equitably, accessibly, with an emphasis on member participation. You can read more about our guiding values at the bottom of this page.

We also are committed to a dynamic collective decision-making process; members will agree upon the value of commodities, resources and labor. To start us out, we created a system of valuation for the books. Each book is assessed cooperatively by the member donating it and by a neutral party working on behalf of the co-op; the factors that determine the book’s value are usefulness (is it a text for a class?), physical condition, market value, and awesomeness.

We started advertising ourselves to the Oberlin community at the end of the semester and were happy and relieved to discover that we weren’t the only ones who thought this co-op was a great idea. We had a great kickoff event and tabled for a few weeks and over those few weeks 80 people came to us with their books, wanting to be members!

 

What’s next

After going public at the end of last semester, we already have a space for our office/inventory and around 700 books … but only a couple bookshelves. We need your help with the bookshelves and other start-up costs. We have plans to pursue more sustainable funding for our long term operating costs, but we need to get our space set up NOW. It’s critical that we have our inventory organized and ready for the beginning of the school year.

 

Here’s what you can do

If you’re able to spare some dollars, we’d really appreciate it. Your donation will make immediate and tangible impact on the co-op. To show our appreciation, we’ve come up with some pretty cool perks, which you can claim on the right side of this page.

If you aren’t able to be donate money right now, we’d love your help finding people who can. Seriously, if you believe this co-op is a worthy organization, talk it up to your friends, parents, and any Oberlin alumni that you know. Encourage them to check out this campaign page.

If you’d like to stay in the know about the co-op’s future endeavors, “like” our Facebook page and/or sign up for our mailing list on our website.

 

More about our budget

Spring 2013

Kickoff event: $45

Website expenses: $30

Fall 2013

Office supplies: $105                                                              

Printer paper, manila folders, writing implements, paperclips, binders, office tape, rubberbands, hole puncher, etc.

Bandwidth for the website: $25

In addition to being a source of information about SWAP, the website will also soon have a database of our inventory that members will be able to search.

Space upkeep: $50

Cleaning supplies, trashbags, etc.

Inventory Expenses: $140

Book tape, stickers for categorizing books, bookends, file holders, shelf labels, filament tape, etc.

Event Expenses: $80

While most of our funds will be used for the upkeep of our space and our inventory, we also want to have events to engage and educate members and other people who might be interested in becoming involved. In our experience, the most successful events of this nature have a small budget that allows for postering around campus, snacks, etc.

Furniture: $225

Bookshelves, desk, wood/paint/screws/nails for building some custom made bookshelves that will allow us to fully utilize our small office space

 

More about our guiding values

Participation

  • Participation in the decision-making process should be encouraged and made accessible to all relevant stakeholders. It is crucial that everyone be allowed to take part in decision-making to ensure that our decisions align with our shared and communal values.

Democracy

  • All power is inherent in the people. We define democratic control of the cooperative as ‘one member, one vote.’ No one is given special privileges because of wealth, social status or power. Democracy is a system of organization that is built to be accountable to the needs of every member.

Sustainability

  • To us, sustainability means creating a system that is built to last, both socially and environmentally. When we act and make decisions, we should use holistic systems thinking. Our structure is adaptable, such that our institution will continue to thrive over time.

Equity

  • Our small organization seeks to drive larger structures towards equitable distribution of power and resources. Every member is expected to act and make decisions according to the notions of fairness and justice they have developed through their lived experience.

Access

  • Every aspect of our institution should be accessible to everyone. We operate within an anti-oppressive framework. No one will be discriminated against on the basis of sex, gender, gender identity, race, ethnicity, class, sexual orientation, religious identity, ability, nationality, citizenship status, presentation, body size, education level, political affiliation, age, housing status, OSCA membership, chronic illness, or mental health.

story:
Summary

Santa Fe College Foundation is on a mission to establish a new scholarship and you can be a founding member:

  • Join us for our celebration event, Santa Fe-st, at noon on September 28, 2013 behind the Fine Arts Hall on the Northwest Campus.
  • See live bands, tour campus, shop the food trucks.
  • Support local students by contributing to the new scholarship!

Santa Fe College is a Top Ten college in the United States, as ranked by the Aspen Institute.  We are an open enrollment college serving traditional students, adult students, part-time students, basically anyone and everyone in our community pursuing their education!

Scholarship awards make the difference between many of our students enrolling in college at all.  Please consider giving; every single student awarded is one more person entering the workforce with a solid academic background.

 

Perks:

  • Every cent of the $50,000 raised will endow a new scholarship. Students will receive all of the funds raised.
  • Our kickoff event is funded in part by grant money and community contributions.
  • Donate now and recieve tickets to the Naia Kete concert.

All funds raised will go to student scholarships - $5, $5,000, or all $50,000.

Other Ways You Can Help

Visit our website for more ways you can be involved with Santa Fe College:

http://sfcollegefoundation.org

http://www.sfcollege.edu/
story_txt:
Summary
Santa Fe College Foundation is on a mission to establish a new scholarship and you can be a founding member:

Join us for our celebration event, Santa Fe-st, at noon on September 28, 2013 behind the Fine Arts Hall on the Northwest Campus.
See live bands, tour campus, shop the food trucks.
Support local students by contributing to the new scholarship!

Santa Fe College is a Top Ten college in the United States, as ranked by the Aspen Institute.  We are an open enrollment college serving traditional students, adult students, part-time students, basically anyone and everyone in our community pursuing their education!
Scholarship awards make the difference between many of our students enrolling in college at all.  Please consider giving; every single student awarded is one more person entering the workforce with a solid academic background.
 
Perks:

Every cent of the $50,000 raised will endow a new scholarship. Students will receive all of the funds raised.
Our kickoff event is funded in part by grant money and community contributions.
Donate now and recieve tickets to the Naia Kete concert.

All funds raised will go to student scholarships - $5, $5,000, or all $50,000.



Other Ways You Can Help



Visit our website for more ways you can be involved with Santa Fe College:
http://sfcollegefoundation.org
http://www.sfcollege.edu/

story:
Running 213 kms across the Himalaya to encourage girls to reach their limitless potential. 


I am a big believer that when we push our boundaries, amazing things follow! 

I believe it, because I have experienced it.  I have taken part in mountain expeditions, run 100km ultra marathons and have endured extreme physical challenges in the past. However, even for me, running 213 kms through the Himalayas is well and truly pushing myself out of our comfort zone!  However, I am determined to put myself through this pain to support and encourage other young girls around the world to have the same opportunities and life-changing experiences that I have. 

In November, I am taking on the Manaslu Mountain Trail! A challenging multi-stage trail race passing through some of Nepal’s most beautiful Himalayan landscapes in a part-circumnavigation of Manaslu, the world’s eighth highest mountain.  

Over 7 days I will run 213 kms at very high altitude, including a "run" over a 5,100m pass!  I am doing it to raise funds for SisuGirls and Trail Running Nepal to support them in their mission in encouraging girls to be determined, brave and resilient through adventure-programs like running, rock-climbing and skateboarding. 

I have been fortunate enough to have the opportunities, funding and support to take part in life-changing adventures like this, but for many other young women that is not the case, and I truly believe these challenges allow girls to develop important life skills.  I short, I really feel passionate about all young women having access to these opportunities. 

I want to raise $2,000. 

Funds will be allocated to SisuGirls and their partner, Trail Running Nepal to help develop the SisuGirls programs and to provide critical funding for girls in Nepal to take part in trail running through the Girls Running Fund. 

In September, Trail Running Nepal funded Mira Rai, a young Nepalese woman to travel to Europe to compete on the world trail running stage.  By funding Mira, they not only encouraged her to reach her highest potential (she came first in two major events), but by allow Mira to reach her goals, they also inspired other girls in Nepal to pursue their running dreams and to understand that the sky is the limit. 

Why?

Running, rock climbing, skate-boarding and all other adventure activities are a gateway to becoming fit and strong, to challenge yourself in a measurable way, to build confidence and a sense of achievement, to get into nature, to meet new people, and to have fun. 

All too often girls sidestep these activities because they don't think they can, because they're "boys' sports" or they're not encouraged to try. Yet the evidence increasingly suggests that girls who take on these kinds of challenges go on and continue to push boundaries as women.

    How you can help

    First and foremost, I really welcome and appreciate your donations! I would love to support SisuGirls and Trail Running Nepal and see more girls taking up these programs and more Nepalese women on the trail running circuit. 

    Secondly, I would love your help in getting the word out about SisuGirls and Trail Running Nepal: sharing on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, G+ or your chosen online or real-life networks of choice increases our chances of getting more girls in the skatepark, on the climbing wall and running trails.

    Thank you so much for the support.

    Jane

story:
-UPDATE-

  As of right now, the total of donations that I received through cash and checks is equal to $2,450, leaving me at a total of $3,700 raised together with this indiegogo account. Thank you for the support thus far and please continue donating, sharing this page, and praying for me!

Why send me to Oxford?

My name is Matthew Diep and I am an 18-year-old, first-year psychology major attending Pasadena City College. I currently compete on a collegiate level dance team, teach tennis, tutor, and mentor while maintaining a 4.0 GPA. I'm currently working to finish my general education requirements, but my end goal is to finish my Ph.D. The reason I'm pursuing a degree in psychology is because I want to make a difference in the way people approach treatment for mental illness. In this society of 'quick fixes' many people who are diagnosed with mental disorders are moving away from psychotherapy and often resort to taking medications because they think they will be healed quickly and permanently. This is misleading as patients often become dependent on these prescribed drugs which result in less healing and more damage to the patient's mental health. With my higher degrees, I will be able to do research and make a positive impact on the improvement of our mental health system. Being able to study abroad in Oxford for a semester will help me gain a new perspective of our world which will be extremely beneficial for my academic goals. 

What I Need & What You Get

My school is offering a program for me to study at Oxford for this coming Spring semester of 2015; however, the cost is roughly $10,000. Because of our current financial situation, my family and I are only able to afford $2,000 of the full amount which includes my parent's contribution and my contribution from my tutoring job. If I do not reach my fundraising goal, I will have to miss out on this amazing opportunity that would expand my network and broaden my mind by allowing me to experience new cultures as well as learn from a new perspective. This is why I am reaching out to you, my network of family and friends, to donate as much as you are willing to help me afford this great opportunity. All the money that I raise will be used towards paying for this trip and I will end this campaign as soon as we reach the goal of $8,000. I will be posting a link to a photo blog of my experience at Oxford so that you may all see the impact of your donations. This blog will run from February 6th, our arrival date, until April 25th, the day we return.

    The Impact

    This once-in-a-lifetime opportunity is going to help me grow so much as a person. I will gain insight by looking at the world from a new perspective which will benefit my pursuit for higher education. The classes I will be taking include: Field Biology, Environmental Science, Scientific Method as Critical Thinking, and Creative Non-Fiction. Ultimately, this trip will contribute to my growth as a leader who is going to make major changes in the mental health system.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Donating money is not the only way you can contribute! Please share this page with any of your friends and family members who you believe will support my goals. Post the link to my campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, etc. If you have any comments, concerns, or questions please email me at: diep_matthew@yahoo.com. Thank you so much!

story:
Rising Sun Community School:  Where Children Learn to Love Learning

Three years ago, Susan Saunders began a small Montessori school in three rooms of a sprawling farmhouse in Floyd, VA after seeing a need for high-quality, child-centered alternative education in the area.  As a certified Montessori teacher, she recognized the benefits of mixed-age groupings, access to the outdoors, and an environment rich with materials that would call to the children and guide them along their own pathway to learning.
That class began with six children and ended with sixteen - a testimony to the time-proven Montessori method, as well as to the need the school was meeting in the community.
Fast forward to three years later, and Rising Sun Community School still operates from the same sprawling farmhouse, but has taken up the entire bottom floor and expanded greatly.  We now have two mixed-age classes.  Our primary class serves children from 2 1/2 to 6, and our elementary class serves children ages 6 - 12.  Both classes are child-led, individually-paced and peace-centered.  Our two lead teachers are both Montessori trained, as is our primary assistant teacher.
Living, working, and learning in a small rural community is full of benefits, and yet, there are also some drawbacks.  The average income is lower.  It is more difficult to find local work.  
Rising Sun remains committed to providing exceptional education at the most reasonable prices possible.  We've made our tuition prices so that Montessori education can be accessible in this community.  We've offered work-trade, barter, and parent hour trade agreements to make it affordable as well as to involve the families.  In short, we have done everything we can to bring the best quality alternative education to our community.
And now, we need your help!
As we grow, so do our expenses, our need for more staff, and our need for more materials.  
Rising Sun has been a beacon of light to the children we serve, and now, it's your turn to help us shine even more brightly!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal of $5000.00 will help us in many ways:

1. Expand our materials in both classes and pay of existing ones;

2. Allow for appropriate shelving and classroom infrastructure;

3.  Allow us to add additional support staff;

4.  Allow us to begin investing in our playscape fund;

and

5.  Allow us to begin a Scholarship Fund and serve even more local children!

It's our belief that Montessori education truly empowers children to go on and make a true difference in their families, their communities, and the world at large.  That's because our unique, holistic approach to learning is tailored to each child, honoring his or her own individual spirit.  Our classrooms are tiny communities, and each child is a proud citizen.  The conflict resolution skills, mindfulness, and communication tools taught in our classes will last for their lifetime.

The success of Montessori graduates is well-known, no matter how you define 'success'.  The founders of Google attribute their divergent, out-of-the-box thinking skills to their Montessori foundations.  Actress Helen Hunt is an outspoken advocate for Montessori, speaking often of how it helped to enable her to think for herself.    More major supporters include Erik Erikson, Sigmund Freud, Buckminster Fuller, Mahatma Gandhi, the Dalai Lama, Fred Rogers, Bertrand Russell, Leo Tolstoy and Alice Waters, just to name a few.

We have a solid, time-tested, proven philosophy that we allow to guide us.  We've proven ourselves to the community after a mere three years - and we are ready to shine even more brightly! And now, we need your help!


Please....share this campaign and keep the light shining!

Every dollar counts.  It truly does!  And sharing the word - spreading this campaign - will help us immensely.  Please contribute whatever you can - and then encourage everyone you know to do the same!

story:
Due to the economic struggles within our inner city schools, Kaizen Accounting Solutions is supporting and sponsoring students by assisting and promoting education to encourage our youth in becoming future leaders.

 

Hogan Middle School is sending several middle school students to Washington DC.  This program is designed to give students hands-on opportunities to interact with government and history in Washington, DC; it is more than just a tour. It is a fast-paced, fun-filled, and educational experience in one of the world’s most dynamic cities. The Staff uses Washington’s key institutions and historic sites as interactive classrooms to help students explore the links between history and the rights and responsibilities of citizens today. This year the students will also have a great opportunity to visit Gettysburg.

 

Since 1971, over 740,000 students and teachers have experienced government in action with this program to Washington, DC. Their participation is made possible through the efforts of partnerships with parents, schools, and generous donors like you.

 

Our students come from all walks of life, including urban and rural communities, as well as those from a wide range of racial, ethnic, and socio-economic backgrounds. This diversity creates a dynamic learning environment where these students can discuss and debate the policy issues impacting our nation today. Critical to this mission is facilitating the participation for students from disadvantaged communities. Often, these young people have the desire to become more active citizens by participating on our Washington programs, but they lack the funds to do so.

 

We believe that the rights and responsibilities of citizenship should be open to all, regardless of financial means. You can help engage the next generation of active citizens by making a donation. We will use your donation to help provide financial assistance to extend our reach to deserving students and teachers across the country.

 

This donation may be tax deductible as the program is registered as a 501(c) 3 nonprofit.
